PETITION.TITLE: Mifepristone
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned showeth:

(1) That the trials of the abortifacient drug Mifepristone (RU486) are against the public interest in that they use women as guinea pigs for trials of a drug which causes death to the unborn future citizens and adds undue risk to the health of women.
(2) That when RU486 is used with a prostaglandin it exposes women to a disproportionate risk of pain, bleeding and more serious complications.
(3) That when RU486 is used as a `morning after pill' its effect is abortifacient in that it stops implantation of a human embryo, a future citizen, in the womb.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will legislate to ban the importation and use of RU486 in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: 25 August 1994
The Hon Laurie Brereton MP
Minister for Industrial Relations
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to Defence Determination 1994/27, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 25 August 1994.

The definition of "deployment" in clause 3 includes service declared by the Minister for Defence to be relevant service. The definition of "operational area" includes an area declared to be such by the Chief of the Defence Force. Subclauses 4.2 and 4.3 confer similar powers on the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. Subclause 5.1 appears to allow the Minister to increase allowances.

The Committee believes that these provisions, particularly subclause 5.1, appear to be subdelegations of legislative power and, as such, invalid unless expressly authorised by the parent Act. In this context the Committee noted the advice in the Explanatory Memorandum that the discretions relate to deployments rather than to individual cases, which indicates that these powers are legislative.

On 16 August 1991 the Committee wrote to your predecessor, Senator the Hon Peter Cook, about similar powers in Overseas Defence Determination 1991/61, although we did not raise the validity of the subdelegation at that time. On 30 September 1991 the Committee was advised that instances of such declarations were rare and would not be used when alternative means were available.
On another point, subclause 5.1 does not provide for the way in which the Minister is to exercise the power to increase the Deployment Allowance.
The Committee would appreciate your advice on the above matters.

The Committee noted the advice in the letter of 8 July 1994 from the Department about other aspects of the present Determination and accepts that special arrangements may be necessary when the safety and security of Australians serving

overseas may be prejudiced. In this context, however, the Committee noted clause 47 of the Legislative Instruments Bill 1994, which provides that a House of the Parliament may require any document incorporated in a legislative instrument to be made available for inspection. It is not necessary for you to address this issue in your reply to this letter, but we mention it as a matter which may affect the administration of some future Determinations.
Yours sincerely
Mal Colston
Chairman
Senator Mal Colston
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee
on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Colston
I refer to my interim reply of 19 September 1994 to your letter of 25 August 1994 to the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Brereton, about Defence Determination 1994/27.

I indicated then that the issues raised were substantial and that I would write to you again when I had considered a detailed report from the Department of Industrial Relations. I apologise for the length of time it has taken to provide you with a substantive reply. In the event, however, your letter gave rise to an unusually complex set of policy and drafting issues which have had to be resolved in parallel, and in consultation with all the interested parties (including the Australian Defence Force, the Attorney-General's Department, and relevant Ministers).

In summary, the Department of Industrial Relations has received legal advice from the Attorney-General's Department indicating that there is a need to rectify some defects in Defence Determination 1994/27, but that the basic approach is valid. A copy of the advice is at Appendix A.

Specifically, I have concluded that it is possible to interpret the definitions of "deployment" and "operational area" as involving invalid subdelegations of legislative power. While the Department's intention was to rely on declarations made independently of the Determination and for a range of purposes unrelated to payment of the allowance, it is necessary to put the matter beyond doubt. The legal advice also identifies a problem to do with the authority for the Determination to rely on such declarations as in force from time to time.

On the other hand, the advice is that the key provisions of clause 4—the authority for the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel to approve threat levels—are a valid subdelegation of an administrative (not legislative) discretion.

The authority for the Minister to approve additional amounts of allowance under clause 5 is probably in the same category, but is more open to question in view of the Minister's discretion to increase the rate within a range rather than by a fixed amount. Again, I recognise a need to put the matter beyond doubt.

In view of these conclusions, action has been taken quickly to amend the Determination to address your Committee's concerns and the associated policy issues. The amending Defence Determination 1994/57 was drafted in consultation with the Attorney-General's Department, and the Explanatory Memorandum gives full details of the effect of the amendments. An advance copy is at Appendix B, and the usual printed copies will be forwarded to Parliament for tabling as soon as possible. A copy of Defence Determination 1994/27 as amended is at Appendix C.
I trust that this meets the Committee's concerns.
Yours sincerely
Gary Johns

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to make a statement relating to the current security situation in Cambodia, to incorporate the statement in Hansard, to also incorporate in Hansard a joint news release from the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) and me on the subject of additional assistance for Cambodia, and to move to take note of the statement and the joint news release.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: CAMBODIA: THE CURRENT SECURITY SITUATION
Parliamentary Statement by Senator the Hon Gareth Evans QC, Minister for Foreign Affairs, The Senate, Canberra, 29 November 1994

1.Australia's involvement in Cambodia flows from a number of national interests: our national interest in removing Cambodia as a source of regional instability and tension; our national interest, as a good international citizen, in relieving to the extent possible the enormous humanitarian problems posed by continuing insurgency in Cambodia; and our national interest in facilitating Cambodia's—and Indochina's—economic and political reintegration into regional and international affairs.

2.These interests remain as valid now as they did when the Australian peace initiative for Cambodia was launched in November 1989, although the economic factor should not be exaggerated. Australia's current trade with Cambodia is insignificant, and realistically cannot be expected to grow until the international rehabilitation and reconstruction effort is much further down the track.

3.Despite the range of Australia's interests, and the intensity of our involvement in the crafting and application of the UN peace plan, it was never our expectation that the plan, however successfully implemented, would be itself a universal panacea for all the many problems confronting the country: it could only give peace a chance. As I noted on the occasion of the signing of the Paris Agreements on 23 October 1991:

The point is simply that peace and freedom are not prizes which, once gained, can never be lost. They must be won again each day . . . In the final analysis it will be the Cambodian people themselves who must take their country successfully through the transitional period, and it is the freely elected leaders of Cambodia who must take their country towards a more prosperous and secure future. The rest of us here wish them well in this great task, and commit ourselves by our signature of these documents to providing all the support and assistance we can.
4.Again, following the successful holding democratic elections in Cambodia, I said in a statement on 4 June 1993:

The important thing to appreciate is that the democratic foundations for the country's future have now been strongly laid, and it is essentially now for the Cambodian people and parties themselves to resolve how they want to be governed. It is neither possible nor desirable for the international community to try to micro-manage each step of the way.

5.The Australian Government has never been either ignorant or naively optimistic about the massive scale of the problems that would have to be dealt with by the newly elected Government, not least the problem of containing the Khmer Rouge (KR) after it walked away from the peace process in 1992. But we have taken the view from the outset that the KR insurgency would be containable and ultimately defeatable—in the same way that communist insurgencies had been contained and ultimately defeated in Malaysia, Thailand and the Philippines—provided there was a government in place with democratic legitimacy, a continued cessation of the kind of direct external support the KR had received in the past, and continued support both for economic reconstruction and national institution-building from the international community. The speed and effectiveness with which the internal security problem could be dealt with would depend a great deal on how united, competent and committed the new Cambodian Government proved to be: the international community could, and should, give every possible assistance, but ultimately the responsibility for progress depended on the elected representatives of the Cambodian people themselves. All this remains our view today.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Involvement of Khmer Rouge in the Peace Plan

SPEECH.PARA: 6.The international community accepted from the outset that there was no viable alternative to a solution involving all four of the Cambodian factions, including the Khmer Rouge (KR), in that plan. The reason was simple: without such an arrangement, the external patrons—particularly China and Vietnam—would not have been able to disassociate themselves from their Cambodian clients, respectively the KR and the `State of Cambodia' (SOC) in Phnom Penh. Without this disengagement, the endlessly destructive civil war would have continued indefinitely.

7.To the extent that China and Vietnam did in fact disengage, that objective has been achieved. Our longer term goal nevertheless remains the continuing reduction, and ultimate removal, of the KR as a factor in the Cambodian political equation—a process which the KR themselves accelerated when they effectively withdrew from the peace process in 1992.

8.The KR does not pose a direct military threat to the existence of the Cambodian Government, which continues to have the support of the bulk of the population and to control most of the national territory. The KR is able to concentrate its forces for limited periods, but it cannot sustain conventional operations on a large scale, primarily due to lack of manpower and dwindling sources of logistical support. It does not have the capability to take and hold a target such as a provincial capital for any length of time. While some recruiting is apparently occurring, including by coercive methods, the KR's current grassroots support is far from sufficient to enable it to significantly expand its numbers.

9.The KR nevertheless poses a severe security problem for the government and this problem is likely to continue in one form or another unless the Royal Cambodian Armed Forces (RCAF) are made more effective. The annual cycle of insurgent activity and military response is also robbing the Government and people of the resources and energy needed for the reconstruction effort upon which Cambodia has made a good start in the year since the formation of the new government. A heightened guerrilla campaign against the Government in the coming dry season cannot be ruled out, but the scale of the fighting is likely to follow an established pattern of skirmishing, guerrilla hit-and-run tactics and terrorist attacks, avoiding large, set-piece battles. The KR also adopt the tactic common in guerrilla wars of establishing a defensible base, usually in a fairly inaccessible area, from which smaller units can spread out over a wider area to stage attacks. The KR has demonstrated that, in current circumstances and without significant international assistance to the RCAF, it is capable of conducting this sort of campaign for some years.

10.Although a signatory of the 1991 Paris Agreements, the KR subsequently refused to cooperate with the disarmament phase of the UN peace plan, and did not take part in the UN-sponsored elections held in May last year. The KR does not recognise the election results as legitimate, and it aims to regain sole power by destabilising the Cambodian Government politically, economically and militarily, through protracted insurgency.

11.The KR is conducting a campaign of military activity in order to damage infrastructure, harass RCAF forces, and promote an impression of widespread insecurity in order to discourage economic development, particularly through foreign aid and investment. Its ongoing warfare is also designed to protect its existing areas of control and to enhance its areas of influence. Related activity includes revenue-raising through trade in timber and gems across the Thai border, and through bandit activity including hostage-taking, levying illegal taxes and making demands for protection money in poorly-defended areas.

12.Military activity is concentrated in the rural areas of north and north-western Cambodia contiguous with the Thai and Lao borders, although skirmishes occur elsewhere. This activity is generally at a low level, with periodic escalations against vulnerable areas or in response to RCAF operations. Casualties are generally few in number. Currently KR units are infiltrating rural areas around the city of Battambang (the nearest large city to the KR HQ at Pailin in north-western Cambodia), but the RCAF looks well able to hold the city should the KR stage an attack. There is also increased KR activity in Siem Reap province (surrounding the Angkor ruins).

13.The KR is a secret organisation closed to outsiders, and it has never been possible to be absolutely precise about KR fighting strength. It is clear however that, claims to the contrary notwithstanding, KR strength has been reduced significantly over the last two years—although a hard core will inevitably remain which is unlikely to defect or be eradicated other than by military means. Our best estimate, based on all available information, is that in 1991 KR military strength was 25,000-27,000 combat troops, with perhaps as many again in support roles. By April 1992, following the arrival of UNTAC, KR numbers had fallen to 20,000-25,000 in total. Currently we judge the KR have no more than 8,000-10,000 men in the field, though in small concentrations scattered around the country. Of this figure, hard-core fighters may be as few as 5000, with the balance comprising porters and support personnel, who act as military reinforcements when necessary. Non-fighting or supporting family members are not included in this figure.

14.The decline in KR strength is due mainly to KR defecting to the RCAF. There were large numbers of KR defections during the UNTAC period, although some of the defectors subsequently rejoined the KR. There has since been a steady trickle of defections to the RCAF, which, assisted by the Cambodian Government's amnesty law, is actively promoting defections as part of its overall strategy of containing the KR. The recent RCAF operation in Kampot Province, which resulted in several hundred KR defections, is an example of this strategy, and there are indications it may serve as encouragement for KR units elsewhere in the country to follow suit.

15.The KR are attempting to counter such losses by using violence and intimidation to obtain forced labour and military reinforcements/porters for the coming dry season. Reports of large scale kidnappings of rural villagers are now being received from a number of provinces in the north and northwest. In late October, the KR kidnapped and subsequently killed about 50 villagers in Bavel District of Battambang Province. Several hundred villagers were also abducted by the KR in Siem Reap province in early November. They are reportedly used as forced labour and also possibly to swell KR ranks. These tactics probably indicate that the KR is becoming more desperate.

16.There has also been a steady decline in both KR areas of control and areas of influence since the middle of 1992. The information available to us indicates that in September 1992 the KR controlled approximately 20-25 per cent of the country, and controlled and influenced 30-35 per cent. In March 1993, the KR's area of control was 15-20 per cent and its area of control and influence 25-30 per cent. In July 1994, its area of control had fallen to less than 10 per cent, and is more likely to be nearer 5 per cent; and its area of control and influence declined to 10-20 per cent. This latest figure will not necessarily hold at this level, given the cyclical nature (dry and wet season driven) of the Cambodian insurgency. To put all these figures into perspective, it must also be noted that, given that the KR tends to be concentrated in some of the least accessible areas of Cambodia, the proportion of the national population which comes under KR control is probably only around 3 per cent of a total population of around 9 million.

17.There is no evidence that the KR leadership has abandoned its ultimate goal of regaining sole power in Cambodia by whatever means possible. Nevertheless, it is reasonable to assume that they must be feeling the effects of increasing political isolation. By not participating in the 1993 UN-organised elections and by reneging on their commitments made under the terms of the Paris Agreements, the KR have extinguished any possibility of gaining a degree of international legitimacy. Following its formation, the Cambodian Government left the door open for the inclusion of the KR in the national polity. Two sets of round table talks were held (in May and June this year) to try to include the KR, and both failed. The KR was formally outlawed by the National Assembly on 7 July 1994. They can expect no further official support from China or Thailand. Strong Thai Government support for the Cambodian Government was reaffirmed as recently as mid-November. The Thai Government has also moved, particularly since July, to stop longstanding relationships and arrangements between freelance Thai military and business elements and the KR.

18.The KR are also under some military pressure. In mid-1993 (ie. following the Cambodian elections), KR policy changed from rejecting the UNTAC process and seeking to disrupt it, to calling for all parties to accept the election results. This about-face by the KR was probably to encourage Prince Sihanouk to find a means of including them legitimately within the national polity, under the rubric of "national reconciliation". Although the RCAF's last dry season offensive failed to meet its over-ambitious objectives (see paras 19-20 below) the RCAF did, for a time, force the KR onto the defensive in parts of their heartland.

19.These combined pressures, however, have so far been insufficient to force any real change in the KR's underlying strategy and objectives. An assessment of KR intentions based upon their behaviour in the post-UNTAC phase indicates that the KR is unlikely to negotiate to the extent of disarming, or allowing government access to the areas under KR control. This would inevitably weaken the KR's hold over its population base and further threaten its remaining trade in gems and timber. Disarming its fighting forces or merging them into the RCAF would remove the KR's only means of exercising exclusive power in Cambodia.

20.In the longer term, the KR may be pinning its hopes upon an expectation that corruption, faltering economic progress and factional divisiveness will split the government and erode its support among the Cambodian people, enabling the KR to assume power. They may also believe that their advantage lies in a long campaign of guerilla warfare to wear down the government, constrain economic development, deter foreign investors and donors, and foment insecurity—with the aim of leaving the government no alternative, if peace is to be obtained, other than to offer the KR a power-sharing role. This is an unlikely outcome since the elected government is strongly opposed to it. And even if the KR were to become part of the government process, all the evidence suggests that they would not relinquish their ultimate aim of acquiring exclusive power.

21.If the KR continues its open defiance of the central Government, Cambodia is likely to face a protracted internal insurgency situation not uncommon in South East Asia over the past forty years. However, we would not see such an insurgency seriously threatening the viability of the Cambodian Government in the short term. Over the longer term, prospects would depend on the effectiveness of the government in delivering fair government, economic development and security, as well as the commitment of the international donor community to support Cambodia's economic development.

22.The RCAF's response to KR harassment has been patchy and indecisive. It did manage to capture some traditional KR areas, including Anlong Veng (in northern Cambodia) in February this year and the KR's headquarters town of Pailin (in the north-west) in March. In both cases, however, the KR was able to successfully employ classic insurgency tactics, allowing the ill-prepared and over-confident RCAF force to seize an area which it then could not hold against concerted insurgent harassment. The KR regained ascendancy in the Anlong Veng area after two weeks, and recaptured Pailin after a month.

23.The extent of the government's reverses in Anlong Veng and Pailin should not be underestimated. RCAF forces showed poor discipline, inadequate training, low morale and inability to get equipment and supplies to forces who needed them. Rather than the original victories serving to underline the RCAF's credibility, these subsequent defeats served to highlight its many and fundamental weaknesses as a military force. In many ways worse was the negative impact on national morale, and it could be said that the recapture by the KR of Pailin marked the end of the honeymoon period for the Cambodian Government, both with its people and with the international community.

24.The cycle of diminished military activity during the wet season (April-November) and more aggressive actions by the RCAF during the dry season (December-March) is likely to continue—although the two Prime Ministers have stated that the RCAF will not be mounting major offensives against the KR in the coming dry season as they did in the last. The RCAF will concentrate instead on a strategy of containment. Nevertheless, the dry season is likely to see an increase in the overall level of military activity, even if the RCAF does not embark on an offensive against the KR strongholds of Anlong Veng and Pailin. Military encounters could also be sparked by a significant KR attack in one area or another—and there is already speculation about this prospect.

25.The outlook is for a long period of low-level warfare, with the RCAF not seeking to push the KR out of the core areas they control, and the KR facing greater difficulty in expanding its current areas of control and influence, not least because of increasing re-supply difficulties. Nevertheless, the KR will remain a major problem, preoccupying the security forces and diverting attention and scarce resources from Cambodia's economic and social recovery. In that regard, perhaps the KR's most effective course will be to undermine and damage the RCAF's intangible assets such as morale, confidence and sense of purpose.

26.RCAF strength on paper is about 130,000 but a more realistic figure would be less than 100,000, the difference being accounted for by "ghost soldiers" who remain on the payroll to help boost the income of unit commanders. The RCAF's structure has been further distorted by the excessive numbers of senior officers, many of whom have purchased their ranks or were given them as political rewards. The RCAF's capability and performance is also hampered by infrastructural weaknesses, attributable to lack of budgetary support and financial accountability; morale and discipline problems; inadequate training; and continuing factional allegiances within the amalgamated force.

27.These problems should not, however, be regarded as too unexpected since the RCAF was formed barely a year ago from the forces of formerly opposing factions (the then Phnom Penh regime's CPAF on the one hand, and the anti-communist KPNLAF and Sihanoukist ANKI on the other) who had fought a bitter guerrilla war for over a decade. The troops had different loyalties, different levels of training and experience and were competing for the same limited resources. The varying interests of their commanders and officers had to be accommodated as did their concerns over rank and job security.

28.These inherent difficulties were, and continue to be, compounded by the fragile political and economic environment of Cambodia which to an extent makes the problems confronting the RCAF almost inevitable. Rectifying them will thus require concerted planning and action at various levels. Nowhere in the world has the attempt been easy to amalgamate formerly opposing forces into a new army with a national sense of identity and purpose. The current difficulties being experienced in South Africa bear witness to that. Cambodia is no exception and the RCAF needs both time and encouragement to deal constructively with these problems.

29.Despite these problems, the senior RCAF leadership has recognised the tasks ahead through an expressed commitment to reform, loyalty to the government and reasonable reliability in handling political incidents to date. The Chief of Staff, General Ke Kim Yan, is a highly professional officer with a realistic approach to the challenges before him, as demonstrated during his visits to Australia and other countries to discuss Cambodia's military situation.

30.The RCAF has made a tentative start on its ambitious reform program, which was approved by both Prime Ministers in August 1994. The RCAF sees its main strategic aim as the defeat of the KR, which is to be achieved through reform of the RCAF, destroying the KR's logistics bases, improved rural development, and increased foreign military assistance.

31.If these goals are to be achieved, the RCAF recognises that it will have to become a smaller, better trained and more disciplined professional force. The RCAF has developed a plan that addresses the immediate and longer-term problems. To be implemented over three years, the plan aims to reduce the RCAF to 70,000 personnel. The new force will include counter-insurgency battalions to pursue the KR, while six divisions will be retrained to protect economic and social development in strategic government-controlled areas.

32.The implementation of rank reductions has commenced, with personnel being reduced to a rank commensurate with their level of command and duties. Ultimately, the number of generals will be reduced from some 2000 to 90. To set an example, both Defence Ministers and Chief of Staff Ke Kim Yan have been reduced from 4-star to 3-star generals. Military regions have established committees to oversee rank reductions. It is expected that this phase of the rank reduction process will be completed in about two months, despite resistance from some quarters. Basic training appears already to be taking place in some military regions.

33.The RCAF is not in immediate danger of collapse, even if it does not receive international military assistance. The military outlook is for a long period of low-level fighting, with the RCAF unable to gain control of territory held by the KR and, equally, with the latter facing great difficulty in expanding its areas of control and influence.

34.Much will depend on popular attitudes towards the KR and the government in rural areas. Although our knowledge of this is necessarily incomplete, indications are that the appeal of the KR to poor rural dwellers has more to do with their dissatisfaction with the RCAF and lack of any discernible improvement in their daily lives than with any intrinsic appeal of KR philosophy or programs. Even if the KR cannot expand significantly, we do not exclude the possibility that this trend will become more pronounced and more widespread—although the KR's increasing resort to coercive tactics in some areas will obviously count against them. Chronic low-level instability also encourages the emergence of spheres of power centred on provincial administrations, and only tenuously overseen by a preoccupied central authority, notwithstanding its recent attempts to centralise revenue-raising.

35.In the longer term, an improved security force is therefore vital in stabilising the Cambodian Government and marginalising the KR. International military assistance can play a valuable role in enabling the RCAF to develop the discipline and skills that it needs to achieve such an improvement as well as instilling a sense of confidence in the government to manage this very difficult period of transition and reform. Nevertheless, it cannot be overstated that international military assistance is not the sole solution to the RCAF's difficulties, let alone those of Cambodia more generally.

36.Improvement in the effectiveness of Cambodia's armed forces, moreover, is only one factor in marginalising the KR. As with any insurgent force, the KR cannot be defeated by military means alone. The government must also improve the living standards of the majority of the people, who live in the countryside. In order to do so, the government needs more than a better security force: it must also make progress toward achieving an efficient and effective bureaucracy, improved rural services, more jobs and a rehabilitated economic infrastructure. Moreover, it must develop more political cohesion, and restrain factional squabbling. If the government does not face these issues, no amount of military assistance will be able to bring stability to Cambodia.

37.Representations made by the Australian and other governments along these lines appear to have had some impact on the Cambodian Government's sense of its own responsibilities in this respect. The RCAF must reform and restructure itself if the international community is to have confidence in Cambodia's commitment to reform and if foreign aid is not to be merely a temporary band-aid. A start has been made, but it must be developed and consolidated by the Cambodians themselves, even with substantial external advice and assistance.

38.Australia is not alone in providing defence assistance to Cambodia. Belgium, Canada, France, New Zealand, the Netherlands, Norway and the US, like Australia, all have personnel involved in mine clearance. France has a significant military assistance program, including training of RCAF personnel. Russia has supplied a team for the maintenance of helicopters and other aircraft. The United States has approximately 45 defence personnel in Cambodia providing humanitarian, demining, construction and road-building assistance; thirty-six pieces of heavy construction equipment to support these activities arrived in Phnom Penh in July. China and Thailand have provided uniforms, with Thailand also offering to provide some civic action and engineering training to the RCAF. Indonesia and Malaysia are prepared to provide training assistance.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Safety of Australians in Cambodia

SPEECH.PARA: 39.The underlying factor in any security assessment of Cambodia is that no area in-country, including Phnom Penh, is absolutely safe. However, some areas are safer than others. Phnom Penh and some provincial towns are the safest, although violent crime is now rife in Phnom Penh. Security in the countryside is uncertain given the potential for rapid change in the security circumstances of any province. Certain areas, for example Banteay Meanchey, Battambang, Preah Vihear, Siem Reap (in the north and north-west) and until recently Kampot (south-west of Phnom Penh), are more dangerous than others, although this too changes over time. (The threat in Kampot currently appears to be reduced by the success of the defection strategy that took place during the final phase of the Wilson abduction. Several hundred KR fighters and their families joined government ranks.) There are threats from sources other than the KR, such as regular acts of banditry, including by members of the RCAF, and a general climate of violence in a society that has endured decades of civil war, the US bombings, the Lon Nol excesses; and the horrors of the "killing fields". However, the KR are the essential security problem, and aid workers and other foreign personnel in the provinces are probably most at risk, particularly if (as KR radio has asserted from time to time) local cadres have been directed to target Westerners. The total number of foreigners in Cambodia is about 10,000, including diplomats, UN employees, aid workers with NGOs and business people but excluding ethnic Vietnamese and Vietnamese workers who number in the tens, if not hundreds, of thousands.

40.There are currently 368 Australians registered with the Australian Embassy in Phnom Penh (including some Australian citizens of Cambodian background) of which 38 are based in the provinces. Many of these people work for NGOs dedicated to the betterment of living conditions of the Cambodian people. Often they have many years of experience in Cambodia and are well placed to judge the current security situation on the ground in particular districts. These figures, however, almost certainly understate the true number of Australians in Cambodia at any one time as they do not include unregistered residents, casual travellers, tourists or consultants with international agencies or NGOs who may enter the country for limited periods.

41.The current Consular Travel Advice for Cambodia prepared by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade was issued on 25 November. It emphasises that the security situation is very uncertain and advises that non-essential travel outside Phnom Penh—with the possible exception of organised trips by air to Angkor Wat—should be avoided. Australian residents and visitors are urged to register their presence with the Embassy and to seek advice on the current security situation prior to any travel. Previous Consular Travel Advisories issued this year have had as their constant themes the uncertain state of security prevailing in Cambodia and the need for Australian travellers to exercise due care and maintain a very high level of security awareness at all times.

42.The Embassy holds regular security briefings for the Australian community and runs a warden system which facilitates the quick dissemination of relevant information. For those with essential business outside Phnom Penh, the Embassy advises, and itself obeys, good security practices such as only travelling in convoy, seeking armed official protection where necessary and avoiding night-time travel. The Embassy is also in close touch with other diplomatic missions and the United Nations Development Program which provides a security network for the hundreds of employees with UN agencies scattered throughout Cambodia, including in areas of high KR activity.

43.Since the abduction of David Wilson, both the Embassy and AIDAB have made specific arrangements to inform NGO head offices of the increased threat to aid workers who may have cause to travel outside Phnom Penh. A special security briefing, involving several DFAT officers, was held in Canberra on 12 September for NGOs with programs in Cambodia and further briefings will be given as necessary. In implementing Australia's current aid program and planning future activities, AIDAB gives absolute precedence to the safety of staff. This may result in the restriction of some activities in rural areas.

44.While we currently believe that Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel, of whom there are currently 15 in Cambodia (including the Defence Attache and his Assistant), are probably at no greater risk than civilians from the KR, increasing KR radio rhetoric indicates that foreign military advisers would be their preferred targets. ADF personnel, in accordance with the Defence Cooperation Program, are improving the communications system of the RCAF, undertaking demining activities with the Cambodian Mine Action Centre and teaching English to the RCAF. Defence has instituted strict security measures for ADF personnel, which include protection by the RCAF at all work sites. The overall military threat to ADF personnel in Cambodia is currently assessed as medium in Phnom Penh and provincial towns and medium to high in some areas of the countryside. With the announcement of additional military assistance, it is expected that the threat will remain at medium for Phnom Penh and most provincial towns, but may become high in some towns in the north-west. The threat in the countryside is likely to become high. There will likely be a parallel increase in the risk to Australian civilians who live permanently, or undertake necessary periodic travel, outside Phnom Penh.

45.Regrettably, the safety of Australian nationals (and Canadians for whom Australia has consular responsibility) cannot be guaranteed by the measures outlined in paras 38-40 above. Australians must make their own decisions about safety, travel and work in Cambodia—doing so with an awareness of the increased risks involved. The Australian Government can provide the type of information they need to make an informed decision, but at the end of the day has no power to prevent Australians from visiting or working in Cambodia.

46.Unfortunately, any intimidation of the international community in Cambodia resulting in restriction of assistance programs would be a victory for the KR. Rural Cambodia desperately needs development assistance and the building of infrastructure of every type, including clinics and schools. The KR have shown their true colours when they recently refused to guarantee that the workers of the reputable organisation Medecins Sans Frontieres would be left unmolested. The KR are out to disrupt, discourage or prevent these activities because they know that they can only flourish in a poor and isolated countryside and that rural development will make the KR irrelevant to the life of the peasantry. The recent upsurge in KR abduction of villagers in north and western Cambodia underlines their determination to intimidate locals as well as foreign nationals. Rural development thus holds the key to their ultimate defeat, but such development will not take place without security. The international community must therefore provide Cambodia with assistance in the fields of both development and security. One is not a substitute for the other—both are essential. The Australian Government is committed on both fronts, and despite the KR's threats to foreigners, will remain committed.

47.The international community has an immediate humanitarian imperative to help Cambodia's reconstruction. After more than thirty-five years of conflict the countryside has been ravaged, the population decimated and demoralised, and nearly all infrastructure destroyed. Between one and two million people were killed by the KR or died under their rule, and others—including many of those most needed for the country's development—fled the country. With a current per capita income of about US$210 per annum, Cambodia's nine million people are amongst the poorest and most disadvantaged in the world.

48.In judging the way Cambodia is dealing with its problems today and how we and the international community can help lift the country out of poverty, turmoil and poor government, it has to be borne in mind that the Cambodian Government, the bureaucracy and the armed forces are just one year old, and made up of factions that were formerly at war with one another. In the post-UNTAC period the Cambodian Government has faced the enormous and urgent task of rebuilding the country from scratch. It is evident that Cambodia will need substantial long term international assistance in this task. The economy needs major structural development and reform. It lacks adequate infrastructure, power and communications; industry and manufacturing, to the extent they exist, are badly run down; the country lacks a skilled and trained labour force; public administration and government is terribly weak; health and education services need to be rebuilt; and the judicial and regulatory systems are virtually non-existent. The situation is further complicated because of inadequate administrative structures, corruption, political uncertainty and real concern about security.

49.Cambodia is fragile and vulnerable and it will remain so for some time. But it is in better shape than it was a few short years ago. The international community will have to give Cambodia time, certainly some years, before it is truly off the danger list. Economic development is the key to long term prosperity of Cambodians and the survival of the government. It is imperative, however, if economic development is to have a chance, that there be security in the country.

50.Gradually pledged international assistance is coming on stream. In 1992/93 the International Conference on the Reconstruction of Cambodia (ICORC) noted that multilateral sources (IMF, World Bank, and UN Agencies) had distributed some US$111.4 million. A further US$474 million was distributed from bilateral sources. In March this year, donor governments and agencies pledged a further US$486 million through ICORC for 1994 and US$271 million for 1995. In addition, in May this year the IMF approved a three year structural adjustment facility of US$120 million for Cambodia. Donor governments believe Cambodia should be responsible for receiving and managing aid, and to date have been pleased by the efforts of the Cambodian Government. Understandably, its capacity to absorb large-scale assistance is limited and the international community will need to be patient.

51.Despite the magnitude of the problems facing it, Cambodia is making progress. The IMF in a recent review of the Cambodian economy expressed satisfaction with the Government's economic reform and liberalisation measures, and paid tribute to its success in getting a national reconstruction plan launched, in passing a foreign investment law and in improving, tax, customs, trade and public finance procedures. The Fund said Cambodia's economic performance was positive and that it had done well given the constraints it faced. The Fund expressed concern, however, about the slow rate of disbursement of international donor pledges and noted that this was holding up much needed reform in key sectors such as agriculture. Australia, for its part, has been diligent in disbursing its pledges.

52.International financial institutions conclude that despite these difficulties, the economy, while starting from a very low base, was showing quite a respectable 6 per cent rate of growth and modest levels of investment were beginning to materialise. The rate of inflation was being held down to around 8 per cent compared with 41 per cent the year before. These were substantive achievements but the international donor community would need to maintain its commitment if these reforms were to bear fruit.

53.Australia will not give up on the Cambodian people. Our civil development aid commitment to Cambodia is A$92 million over the next four years (94/95-97/98). Australia's aid program—ranked sixth in 1993 after France, the United States, Sweden and the Netherlands—aims to promote good governance, foster political and social stability, provide for poverty alleviation, and promote sustainable economic progress and human resource development. The program is targeted at areas of greatest need, namely rehabilitation of infrastructure, education, health, agriculture, demining and human rights.

54.In this effort Australia works closely with the Cambodian Government, the UN and its agencies, the IMF, World Bank and other international financial institutions including the Asian Development Bank and with NGOs. Australia is a member of ICORC and will be participating in the next meeting in 1995.
JOINT NEWS RELEASE
ADDITIONAL ASSISTANCE FOR CAMBODIA

The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans, and the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, announced today that the Government had approved a further $5 million package of assistance to the Government of the Kingdom of Cambodia.

The package will supplement the substantial assistance already being given by Australia under the current Defence Cooperation program and is aimed at helping the Royal Cambodian Armed Forces (RCAF) become institutionally more efficient. The additional measures announced today consist of a one-off $3 million package of defence assistance to the RCAF and up to $2 million in financial support for demobilisation of RCAF soldiers funded from the current bilateral aid allocation.

Australia is already providing Cambodia with assistance under the Defence Cooperation program worth $3 million this year. This assistance is in the form of mine clearance, the installation of a military communications system, establishment of a maritime workshop and English language training for Cambodian military personnel.

Australia is also committed to a bilateral civil aid program of $92 million over the four years to 1998, covering child health care, education, human rights, rehabilitation of infrastructure, agriculture and further demining assistance.

"The additional defence assistance will focus specifically on training. No Australian personnel will be involved in any support or advisory role during RCAF combat operations. The package will consist of helping the RCAF design an overall training program for its personnel, training RCAF junior officers in Australia as instructors, and providing design assistance and funds so that the RCAF can construct an additional training facility. Some equipment will also be provided for use in training", the Ministers said.
The package does not include the provision of lethal materiel.

The Government's decision is in response to the request from the Cambodian Government to Australia and other governments for additional assistance to the RCAF. The Australian assistance complements the help being provided by other donors. Belgium, Canada, France, New Zealand, the Netherlands, Norway and the US, like Australia, all have personnel involved in mine clearance. France has a significant military assistance program, including training of RCAF personnel. The United States is providing humanitarian, demining, construction and road-building assistance. China and Thailand have provided uniforms, with Thailand also offering to provide some civic action and engineering training to the RCAF. Indonesia and Malaysia have also indicated they are prepared to provide training assistance. The support for demobilisation of excess RCAF personnel will allow appropriate programs to be developed in consultation with the Cambodian Government and the international donor community. These programs will include support for existing programs of job creation, vocational education and micro enterprise development.

The Ministers noted that this assistance is essential to ensure that former soldiers do not resort to banditry or other disruptive activities, and are helped to re-integrate into the civilian community.
"Demobilisation will also allow the remainder of the RCAF better access to training and to use limited resources more effectively," they said.

The Ministers also noted that Australia's additional assistance is fully consistent with the Government's commitment to support Cambodia, assist reform of the RCAF, help create conditions for social and economic development and strengthen regional security.

The Ministers added that the Khmer Rouge, while diminished in strength, remained a serious threat to the efforts of the Cambodian Government to restore peace and provide stability. The continuing conflict meant that scarce resources were being diverted from Cambodia's economic and social recovery.

The Ministers stressed that the security of Australians—officials, ADF personnel, NGO representatives and private citizens—remained one of their prime concerns. The Australian Government would not, however, be deterred by threats from outlaws from providing assistance to the legitimate Government of Cambodia. The security situation will continue to be kept under close and continuous review, and special measures would be taken to ensure that Australians in Cambodia were kept fully briefed on changes in the security situation. In this regard, they also encouraged all Australians residing in or visiting Cambodia to consult the Australian Embassy regularly for advice on the latest security assessment.

Senators Evans and Ray expressed the hope that Australia's additional assistance would be part of a concerted response from the international community to strengthen Cambodian institutions including in the key area of security, with countries like France and the United States as well as Cambodia's neighbours, continuing to assist with military training and institutional support.

"International and regional support for the RCAF will need to be coordinated to maximise its benefits. For its part, Australia will continue to work closely with other donor countries. However, external assistance can only supplement Cambodia's own efforts and responsibilities," they said.

SPEECH.PARA: There is reason for the urgency of today's motion for the suspension of standing orders. It was an extraordinary circumstance to find out, on 14 November 1994, that the annual report of Australian Defence Industries, which plays an important part in Australia's procurement process—and, of course, it is part of a department which receives an appropriation from the government; it is a fully owned government business enterprise—was not to be available until one day after the date of the first Defence estimates committee hearing. PARA.TAB: This motion is urgent because there seem to be a number of people who do not understand that there is a change in the way that estimates have been organised: they are now held in conjunction with the financial year, the basis for that being that the budget portfolio reports tendered in estimates are smaller and that we would have the opportunity at the same time to conduct estimates committee meetings in conjunction with the appropriate annual reports, both of the departments and of the various statutory authorities.

It is not good enough in such a committee for us to be told by the minister:

SPEECH.PARA: ADI does not come before the estimates committee or the legislation committee in terms of estimates. However, ADI, putting in an annual report like ASTA—

or anyone else, can come before the legislation committee as part of its normal duties in reviewing annual reports. ADI is not subject to budget subvention and, therefore, is not an appropriate matter to discuss directly before the committee.

PARA.TAB: If it gets to the point where the minister can decide the level of scrutiny of his department and the statutory bodies, then there is something wrong with this process. TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I want to take issue with some of what has just been said, in particular the suggestion that some senators' questions are not as valuable as other senators' questions at estimates. That is an enormous amount of money. The Senate and the parliament have the right under our system to inquire, if they wish to do so, as to every cent that is spent. If that is to be responsibly done, it follows that there has to be a sequence to it. Therefore, there is an obligation on the members of the committee to follow some order, some sequence. The committee agreed at the start of the hearing that it would follow the layout in the papers before it—that we would go through the programs—and that is what it did.

I do not wish to lecture or to take a position of righteousness on this, but the chairman and I sat through every minute of that hearing. No other member of the committee did that. I find it very hard to be charitable to those who, for whatever reasons, could not afford the time or whose priorities were not high enough to be at the hearing for matters that they now claim are of transcendental importance to them and this chamber.

The other point that has to be made is that this is not the only opportunity; this is not the only time in Senator Margetts's life that she has the chance to examine ADI or any department. We have reformed the Senate's committee structure. This legislation committee now has the opportunity, outside hearing estimates, to call before it with due notice any body related to Defence and inquire into what it is doing, what it proposes to do and what money it proposes to spend. I hope that not only the legislative committee dealing with Defence but all legislative committees take this opportunity so that the parliament, particularly the Senate, becomes better informed about the workings of the departments for which we approve expenditure each year.

I say to Senator Margetts that, firstly, I think she has contributed partly to the unfortunate situation that we are in. Secondly, all is not lost. Not only has the chairman, with enormous generosity, agreed to provide some facility to get Senator Margetts over her present discomfort, but also there are many other opportunities available if she is prepared to operate in a cooperative way. Finally, since I am in a lecturing mode this morning, let me say that this is a—

TALK.START.PARA: —A charitable mode.

We might contest ideas in the chamber with great force and with great vigour, but we basically follow a different style from most other parliaments in Australia. We cooperate. There is an air of give and take. The final point I make is that politics is not a matter of winning every issue every time. In any day in political life, politicians actually lose more issues than they gain. That is the nature of politics—whether they are in the Liberal Party, the Labor Party or any other party. That degree of tolerance and understanding—not to say compassion—is an essential part of successful political life.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment, which has been circulated, in effect applies the new structure from the beginning of the next session and provides for a transitional provision to deal with bills which the government wants passed this session, which we have agreed to have debated this session and which were not bills that were introduced during the last session. That transitional provision is in paragraph (5) of the amendment that I have circulated.

PARA.TAB: If the Senate adopts my amendment, the government will be, in effect, bound by the undertakings that it gave on 18 August 1993 when it committed itself to a more orderly programming for the Senate by undertaking to have legislation introduced in one period of sittings for passage in the next period of sittings except in relation to budget bills. It also said that it would seek exceptions in relation to certain other unforeseen or urgent bills. We believe these further exceptions, unforeseen or urgent, should be dealt with in the terms that I have put, which would mean that the government would have to seek the approval of the Senate before it dealt with such a bill in the same session in which it was introduced.

As you would be aware, Madam Acting Deputy President, we have for years sought to commit the government to a more orderly programming in this place so that the Senate might function more effectively. We are tired of the process whereby the government introduces large packages of legislation at the end of a session and expects them to be debated in a very short period, because the ultimate result is that the work is not done to the standard that we believe is desirable.

We have tried a whole series of mechanisms over the years to force the government towards orderly programming, and the undertaking it gave in August of last year was really a commitment that arose as a compromise from the pressures that we had applied. We somewhat reluctantly accepted that compromise because we would have preferred a more strict regime than what had been suggested. Nevertheless, we accepted that in terms of a compromise.

If we take this as the first example of the government implementing its commitment in the course of this session, the performance of the government has been deplorable. There is very little evidence that it has made any attempt whatsoever to meet its commitment and provide orderly programming for the Senate. I will give just a few examples. These figures are now a week or two old but, as of earlier in November, which was at the beginning of week six of 10 weeks of this session, the government had nominated 57 bills for passage before the end of the sittings. Of those 57, 36 had not been introduced into either house at the beginning of the sitting. So almost half of the bills that it sought to have passed this session had not been introduced in accordance with its commitment.

By week six only 34 had reached the Senate and, of the 34, only four were on the Senate Notice Paper at 23 August—that is, the beginning of the session. So 34 bills had reached the Senate by the sixth week and only four were bills that were introduced in the previous session. There can be no clearer demonstration of a lack of good faith on the part of the government—no real attempt to meet its commitment whatsoever. At that stage, three bills listed for passage in these sittings had still not appeared in either house.

In those circumstances, it seems desirable for us to meet the spirit of Senator Chamarette's proposal today, which we have redrafted in ways that I have described to make it more workable in the circumstance that we are in at the end of this sitting. What the Senate will now be doing is, by order, imposing a regime on the government. It is regrettable that it seems to be necessary for us to do that in order to expect reasonable performance in programming by this government, but so be it. It has forced it upon itself by its misconduct in this regard.

DEBATE.TITLE: CLASSIFICATION (PUBLICATIONS, FILMS AND COMPUTER GAMES) BILL 1994

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Reynolds, I present the report of the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies on the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Bill 1994, together with submissions and the transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report and to incorporate the tabling statement in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The report I am tabling today is the committee's unanimous report on the provisions of the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Bill 1994 as referred to the committee by the Selection of Bills Committee.

The Bill provides for the classification of films, publications and computer games. It constitutes the Commonwealth's contribution to revising the current censorship laws in co-operation with the States and Territories.

After receiving the reference from the Selection of Bills Committee the committee wrote to each of the State and Territory Ministers responsible for censorship matters and invited their comments on the Bill. Responses received from the Censorship Ministers for Queensland, New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory indicated that the Commonwealth had fully consulted with the States and Territories in the development of the Bill and that the Bill had received their support. The co-operative nature of the Bill was influential in the committee recommending that the Bill be agreed to.

However, the subject matter of the Bill was not new to the committee, it having previously made recommendations about the classification process in its October 1993 report entitled Report on Video and Computer Games and Classification Issues. In particular, the committee was concerned about the lack of responsiveness of the classification system to current community standards and it made a number of recommendations to better involve the general community in the process. While the Bill meets one of the committee's concerns by increasing the number of members of the Classification Board and the Classification Review Board, the Government's response to the committee's other recommendations did not adequately explain their exclusion from the Bill. Therefore the committee has repeated its earlier recommendations for further consideration by the Attorney-General and anticipates that the Attorney-General will consult with his State and Territory colleagues and will address these recommendations in the Government's response.

Finally, the committee received representations from the Video Industry Distributors Association (VIDA) seeking exemption from the classification system of "G"-rated films and videos containing depictions of classical music and sport. Representatives of VIDA appeared before the committee on 20 October to give oral evidence in support of their proposals. The committee saw VIDA's representations as uncontentious, although officers of the Attorney-General's Department advised the committee that the Standing Committee of Censorship Ministers had not agreed to VIDA's suggestions. The committee understands that negotiations between the parties are continuing. It is the committee's intention to meet again with representatives of VIDA on the issues they have raised to assess the developments following the negotiations.
I commend the report to the Senate.
