The government has offered no justification for expanding that waiting period back to 26 weeks. We see every justification for maintaining it.

We will seek to replace the proposed definition of `homeless', which is listed as `unreasonable to live at home' in the youth training allowance legislation, with that of the current definition contained in the Social Security Act. I return to the theme that I spoke about at some length before, that this is a case of consistency. A large part of what this bill is about is shuffling great, bulky pieces of legislation out of one act and into a new one. If we are going to do that, we should at least be consistent with existing things.

It is acknowledged generally that the proposed definition that is based on the current Austudy definition is somewhat harsh and more stringent. I quote from a recent report by the Institute of Family Studies, entitled Family Matters. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The wording of the corresponding Austudy requirements suggest that life in the parental home needs to be somewhat more intolerable before homelessness is recognised. The homeless rate of Austudy is paid when conditions at home would pose a threat to the physical or psychological health of the applicant, including situations of serious domestic violence, sexual harassment, extreme family breakdown or other exceptional circumstances.

We appreciate arguments by the government for consistency, but we fail to see the benefits of this renewed definition which has more stringent criteria in order for young people to qualify as independent. Having said that, we support the insertion of an away-from-home provision for young people. Of course, this will depend on certification by DEET that the young person needs to live away from home for jobsearch or for training.

PARA.TAB: I found it interesting that the government, in sharing some information with my office yesterday, expected that 20 per cent to 25 per cent of youth training allowance recipients will be homeless. I hope that is wrong because it would alarm me, given that one aim of this legislation is to tighten or clarify the homeless criteria, if we are left with the same number of young people defined as homeless as there are at the moment because approximately 24 per cent of 13- to 17-year-olds receiving jobsearch allowance, sickness benefit or the special benefit also receive the youth homeless allowance.

I wonder what `homelessness' means for a trainee. If a quarter of trainees are homeless, perhaps we should spend a bit more energy on addressing that problem. I think you would share with me, Mr Acting Deputy President, knowledge that a person defined as homeless would hardly be an ideal subject for a traineeship. The disadvantages faced by such a person would mitigate greatly against successfully completing a traineeship. I really wonder what we mean when we say `homeless'. We might discuss that a little more in the committee stage, but I raise that problem now and explain that it will be the subject of our second amendment.

I am concerned about the punitive attitude and pejorative language in the legislation about how young people will be treated and about the attitudes and assumptions of the government. Obligations are being lumped onto the youth side and the government has failed to define the consequent and parallel obligations it has—obligations which should see the government accepting some responsibility for the situation as it is and recognising that it is not all the fault of the young people of this country. If we are talking about pathways, there is not only some obligation to enforce young people to follow a certain path, but also an obligation on the government to see that there is something fruitful and productive—in other words, a job—at the end.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Bell hit the nail on the head. The key issue we should be talking about is jobs. Although there will be general support for the idea that young people should be either studying or training if they are unemployed, these student assistance bills raise problems of logic and equity.

PARA.TAB: For a start, let us recognise, as Senator Bell mentioned, that the problem is unemployment—not training. No amount of training will create jobs which are not there. Perhaps some honourable senators will recall the television program, shown some time back, which showed a young woman from Burnie with certificates from all sorts of training courses—and she still had no job. In that regard, I note with interest the basic criticism by the Welfare Rights Centre that the problem is unemployment and that all this legislation, which is transplanted social security legislation, should be left in the Social Security Act. That is the view of that organisation. Indeed, it is rather bizarre to read the pages of legislation which deal with bereavement through death of a partner or withdrawing money from a superannuation fund, and then remind yourself that all this is about under 18-year-olds.

If the government wants to change the name, fine, it can. I suppose I can handle, as can others around the place, a new set of acronyms. But let us not kid ourselves as to what this is all about: it is about unemployment benefits for under 18-year-olds; that is what it is about. There is a real danger of wasting taxpayers' money on myriad courses which are nothing more than credentialism. Tourism is a very important industry and a fast growing area of employment. It is important, of course, for training schemes to continue in that particular area and be supported strongly. But people do not need to have university degrees to learn how to serve meals or work in the tourist industry at that particular level. It is handy, of course, to have languages in the tourist industry if you are to be face to face with the public and not doing up rooms and so on.

But let us face it: what people want is work, not mickey mouse courses. We have to realise that young people are individually very different. Those of us with families know that each individual child, young person, teenager, young man or young woman is unique; not one of them is the same. Honourable senators ought to get around our tea table at night and they then would know that.

A great failure of the green and white papers on unemployment was in their not addressing fundamental issues, such as pressures on labour force participation rates—even though the Treasurer (Mr Willis) has publicly admitted that the increased rates of participation in the work force of mothers with young dependent children make it awfully difficult to get the unemployment rate down. That is what Minister Willis has said. In this regard, it is disappointing that the government has not addressed the issues posed by some of its commissioned work which pointed to the pressures created by the taxation system on families, which force them to seek second incomes, even when they would otherwise prefer to have one parent at home. It is a disgrace; it is an indictment on us all—on the government in particular—that nowadays the average family needs two incomes whereas previously one income was sufficient.

It is most cynical; one could say that the measure currently before us is another exercise in massaging the unemployment figures. Some will say that the government is trying to massage the unemployment figures by pushing young people to stay on to year 12, go to university or get training—anything to get them off the unemployment rolls. I have asked the Australian Statistician in estimates processes how he will classify people on the youth training allowance. If the Australian Statistician says that people will be classified as being out of the work force and thus not unemployed, then the cynics regrettably will be proved right.

There are other fundamental policy problems with the bill. The bill imposes means tests on young people on the basis of their parents' income and assets. Presumably, the logical basis for this approach is that the parents' income and assets can be regarded as being available to support the young person. Yet, when it comes to taxing the family, the parents are treated as though they had no dependants. This is just another example of the institutionalised hypocrisy which permeates government policies on families.

On the question of family income transfers that can be used to save the Treasury money, families are recognised. But when recognising family responsibilities and family income support that would cost the Treasury money, forget it. Forget the International Year of the Family; forget the slick ads and logos that we have seen on television. What the government is really about is screwing every cent it can out of ordinary families.

I will take another example. There is no allowance for family size in these income and assets tests. We know how the government knocked off the so-called sibling concession which treated a family with more than one student the same as a family with one student. It is repeating that here. There is no allowance in the income test for the number of family members, and there is no allowance in the assets test for the number of family members. Yet the Medicare levy recognises the obvious. It has thresholds which increase with family size.

Under this bill, if a person is married or in a de facto relationship, the parental income test does not apply; he or she is independent. Yet the government has said that Austudy claimants in similar circumstances who are married will not be recognised as independent from 1 January 1995.

It bugs many families when the government rabbits on about income support for families or young people. Who pays the bills? Who pays the mortgage or the rent? By and large the families do. No-one else. Yet the government consistently ignores this vast, voluntary, private redistribution of income. It does not recognise it in the taxation system, so all families with children are discriminated against.

Every week, many more billions of dollars flow to families from workers' pay packets than from any social security payment. Yet these workers get no relief and no recognition from the tax system for what they are doing in saving the Treasury a bundle, as well as raising its future taxpayers.

Finally, I repeat one of the major points that I am concerned about. If the government sees this as an attempt simply to massage the unemployment figures and if, as a result, the statistician classifies these people on the youth training allowance as not being unemployed—as being out of the work force—this is a con job. I will be very interested to hear what the statistician says in response to my questions in the estimates committee.

In respect of the proposed amendments, it is not for me to speak on those at this juncture. Hopefully, I will contribute to the committee stage of the debate although, as I mentioned in a previous debate, if this bill is still in the committee stage tomorrow morning, by a decision of this Senate, I will be at a meeting of the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, of which I am a participating member, in respect of a matter that is of importance to this chamber.

That is one of the reasons why I think we have to look at the problem of committee meetings taking place at times when the Senate is meeting, particularly when the Committee of the Whole is considering a very important bill such as we have here. The alternative to that is to receive the gift of bi-location which, in my case, I do not think would be necessarily appreciated by honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Student Assistance (Youth Training Allowance) Amendment Bill has so many problems with it that it is hard to know where to start. There are two major areas of problems. The first is the way the government has legislated for case management and the rules governing the youth training allowance. The second is the unworkable administration of this new allowance because of DSS and DEET anomalies. Today we should try to alleviate both of these problem areas because, if we do not, it is inevitable that the ones who will lose out, as usual, will be our young unemployed people.

PARA.TAB: The concept of the bill is about changing the name of a training program and pretending that it is a job placement program. There are three reasons for saying that: firstly, it serves the mass processing of clients into training programs and therefore off the unemployment figures, as Senator Harradine mentioned; secondly, it is a paternalistic and short-term approach to the futures of young people, which is meant to give the impression that the government is helping youth to find jobs; and, thirdly, it funds a number of public and private organisations that can cream off their commissions, which are incentives to churn through more clients in a shorter period of time. Once again, the government has wrecked a good idea by building into a program measures that promote the domination of economic efficiency as a criteria for service provision at the expense of quality.

The youth training allowance scheme is paternalistic because in many cases youth will be forced into jobs they do not want but which are instead most convenient for case managers. The case managers will probably be just out of school or university themselves as the government is embarking on a large graduate recruitment in the new year. The economic efficiency measures and the sheer number of cases per person mean that quality time and planning, counselling, and pre-vocational and self-esteem work will be pushed aside. The scheme will therefore not promote different, more caring and equitable ways of dealing with youth but will seek to enhance the already paternalistic style of employment advice used by the CES.

Our young people are very aware of the power structures in the administration of employment systems. It is a complete power imbalance where they are constantly told what they should be doing, as in a parent-child relationship, instead of having their empowerment and sense of choice over their future facilitated by a relationship between functioning adults.

When we have a situation of factory farming people into jobs or training to pull them off the unemployment statistics the fastest and cheapest way possible, the priority becomes that of picking those who are already suitable for vocational training or jobs. This is not necessarily what our young and deeply disadvantaged unemployed people are ready for. The scheme is meant to help the long-term employed, and although length of unemployment is a barrier to employment, it is really the culmination of a whole lot of other barriers that work against a person. Some of these barriers are: ethnicity, age, language skills, isolation from the culture of work, personal development and self-esteem, drugs and alcohol abuse, homelessness and family problems.

These people make up the deeply disadvantaged group in the labour market. Will this scheme help them? They require a focus on personal development and pre-vocational training to prepare them for training and eventual work but, because there will not be any immediate statistical result, they will be put in the too hard basket.

In its recent research report, Down, but not out: helping people most deeply disadvantaged in the labour market, ACOSS found that the best way to help this deeply disadvantaged group was a two-year work plan to get them ready for work. Without this kind of concentration on the deeply disadvantaged, ACOSS says that simple labour market programs will continue not to help them. Instead, what happens again and again with the introduction of new labour market programs is that the 20 per cent of those who are work-ready and who need only a slight skills upgrade are those who are creamed off the surface of the unemployment problem and put to work. I fear that, without some real thought, this new scheme will have exactly the same results.

I suspect that case managers will largely take the role of referring people due to the large case loads they will have to handle. They will not have the time to sit down with people, counsel them on a personal level and help them identify their personal problems and obstacles to finding the training that suits them the best or the mode of work for which they are suitable.

Many will have personal obstacles to work to deal with, and they will have to be given the support to deal with these issues in time. Even though this caring and holistic approach can be more frustrating at times, there is no point in shoving them into jobs that they will not like or that they are unsuited for and then cutting off their only means of support if they later quit or refuse to do the work up-front.

I also believe it is essential that case managers be properly trained to deal with these people in a caring manner. They need to be able to employ strategies for young people to come to their own conclusions and determine their own employment and training needs. Without this, we cannot succeed in the empowerment of the youth in our society, which is what they need most at that vulnerable age.

In terms of case manager training, it is very important that they do not view the young unemployed with disdain and that they maintain a positive attitude towards them. The attitudes of case managers will invariably govern their behaviour towards our young people. They should not blame the victim when it comes to unemployment. As we know, unemployment is the consequence of a complex array of trade, financial speculation and multinational forces that lead to a structural unemployment that no amount of training can change.

Much attention needs to be paid to alternative training schemes or skills that people will need that may lead to self-sufficiency, such as self-employment and cooperative or group enterprises. There are plenty of obstacles in this legislation to stop people turning down this road. The government should have dealt with the problems I have outlined by softening the paternalistic approach and by having a decent appeals process built into the new YTA system. Alas, this is not the case. The review process is the same—through the slow working appeals tribunal already in place—but it will have a heavier workload from reviewing challenges to the activity agreements which are sure to cause problems if case managers assert their will over our youth who need care and time to decide what is best for them.

I am concerned that there is not ample flexibility to vary an activity agreement. There needs to be a built-in principle that such an agreement can be changed and there needs to be a fair process of changing it and appealing the outcomes of those negotiations. It is essential that young people are actively involved in the negotiation of the agreement and that it is not forced on them in a passive position to which they can say yes or no. The bottom line is that there is no opportunity to say no when people are going to lose their only means of support.

We also need to look at what sort of outcome we want for our young people out of this new program. Do we want to shove them off the unemployment statistics for a bit to make the government look better for the next election? Or do we want to put them into a six-month training program and then forget about them? Or do we need to integrate these job training programs, which are dressed up as job placement programs, with real job creation programs to give these kids a chance? At the end of the day, this new program will not help a thing if no new jobs are created. We can blame the victim as much as we like, but the bottom line is jobs—private and public sector jobs, self-employment and group and cooperative enterprises.

I believe it is also important that training programs are not seen as an end measure but as a stepping stone for our young people to acquire the skills they need to get on in life. That will add to their life focus and life-long process of learning. Young people also need follow-up support after training, and case managers should be offering their services for the benefit of young people and not just to gain the most funding they can from this program.

When we are legislating on how to deal with people who strike or lose their jobs voluntarily, we need to emphasise the importance of post-placement counselling. This will keep people in their jobs, work against employee discrimination and help the person acclimatise to the culture of the job and organisation. I fear this will not be a priority for overburdened case managers. In the future we would like to see more emphasis on real job creation and more programs such as the new enterprise scheme and jobskills, which are really about employment and learning, not just about decoration which runs the risk of disempowering our young people in the early stage of their life.

I turn to the problems of the departments in sorting out how to administer this bill. This bill is governed by DEET legislation which is to be administered by the DSS. This is an unhealthy compromise between two ministers who fought over the youth training allowance. We know that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) won but, egos out of the way, the people who will suffer as a result of this situation will be our unemployed young people.

The benefit to the government of putting DSS legislation through the DEET wringer means that definitions are narrowed to DEET standards and fewer people can qualify over independent and away from home rates of allowance. These definitions need to be urgently amended because the DEET definitions are unduly harsh in these areas. The government can keep on with its rhetoric about consistency between DSS and JSA as long as the harsher DEET standards are aligned with DSS criteria—not the other way round.

The other point about the two departments sharing the youth training allowance is that there will be lots of buck passing and lower levels of accountability and efficiency. This point has already been experienced by recipients of the formal training allowance, which was a small allowance of only $40 a week, as it had notorious administration problems caused by DSS acting as an agent for DEET.

In terms of moving this legislation back to DSS and out of DEET's hands, I propose a motion that after 12 months of the program running, on 1 January 1996, the government review the administration of the youth training allowance and produce a report looking into the transfer of that part of the Student Assistance Act which deals with YTA by amendments to the Social Security Act. I trust that all senators will give this motion their serious consideration. I move:
At the end of the motion, add:

SPEECH.PARA: "but the Senate:

(a)notes that the Youth Training Allowance (YTA) which replaces the Job Search Allowance will encounter enormous difficulties in administrative efficiency and accountability due to its joint administration by the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) and the Department of Social Security (DSS);

(b)further notes that in the Government's attempt to remove the anomalies between DSS and DEET criteria, it has used the YTA as a means to usurp the DSS criteria with harsher DEET criteria for homeless and independent rates of allowance;
(c)calls on the Government to urgently investigate administering the YTA solely through the DSS and governed by DSS legislation; and

(d)resolves that there be laid on the table by the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Senator Schacht), on or before the first sitting day in 1996, a report which states:

PARA.TAB: (i)what action the Minister has taken to investigate transferring the YTA to DSS legislation and in particular to the Social Security Act;
(ii)the results of those investigations; and

(iii)the Government's proposals to address the urgent need to administer the YTA through one body and the application of broader DSS qualifying definitions for independence and homelessness than is currently held for DEET allowance recipients".

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask Senator Margetts whether she has circulated that amendment yet.
—Yes.

—The government welcomes the opposition's general support for the Student Assistance (Youth Training Allowance) Amendment Bill, but it does not agree with the amendment proposed by Senator Margetts. I wish to make some comments in passing. The government does not accept the criticism by the opposition and the Australian Democrats that we have not properly consulted on the bill. We have consulted fully with all community groups that have expressed an interest in the bill. The government has made departmental officers available to the opposition and all the minority parties and interests since the bill was introduced in the House of Representatives. Indeed, the government has been very vigorous in the availability of briefing on this important bill. The timings of all briefings were entirely at the choosing of the individual parties concerned.

PARA.TAB: It is clear from Senator Bell's comments that the Democrats wish to drive a wedge between the government and the community groups. That might be a bit harsh, but that is what struck me in some of the comments Senator Bell made in his contribution to debate on this bill. Despite these comments, the government was pleased to reach a consensus with the National Union of Students on the matters raised. Additionally, the government has addressed all the other matters raised. Senator Bell criticised the bill, saying it restricts the situations where a young person can qualify as being independent. The government considers that, in general, young people should be supported by their parents unless it is clearly not appropriate.

However, the government recognises the difficulties faced by low income families who are supporting a young person who needs to live away from home. To meet this issue, the youth training allowance introduces an away from home rate which at present is $222.10 a fortnight. The maximum away from home rate is the same as the maximum independent rate, but it is subject to parental means testing. There is no waiting period for the away from home rate, unlike the independent rate for the jobsearch allowance.

I now turn to the issues of homelessness. The proposed legislation will remove a provision enabling a young person to qualify as homeless if the parents do not let the person live at home. This provision is too broad and is susceptible to abuse and rorting. The present legislation provides that a young person can qualify as independent if he or she cannot live at home because of extreme family breakdown. I trust in this area we will not get some of the exaggerated claims that have occasionally come, unfortunately, from the opposition.

The government has consulted with the Morris committee on youth homelessness about the homeless criteria. The government accepts the committee's view that the youth training allowance criteria should apply across-the-board. The present legislation will make the same definition of homelessness apply for sickness allowance and special benefit. The government is looking at changing the Austudy rules to the same as the youth training allowance.

I will make some comments in response to remarks made by a number of honourable senators in their contributions in the second reading debate. Senator Troeth asked what kind of training young people will receive. It is a requirement of the proposed legislation that a young person receiving the youth training allowance will be approved for training only if this is likely to improve his or her employment prospects. Where young people have assistance from a case manager, this will help them make realistic choices about education and training that is most likely to qualify them for employment.

Of course, it is not possible to guarantee a young person that the training will necessarily lead to employment. Senator Bell may be unrealistic in suggesting that the government guarantee people paid employment as a result of their participating in the youth training initiative. However, the government is committed to providing major resources to assist young people entering the labour market. These include the youth training initiative and additional entry level training places.

Senator Troeth and Senator Bell referred to concerns expressed by the Welfare Rights Centre on why DEET has been given responsibility for the youth training allowance. I think Senator Margetts may have touched on similar points in her remarks just completed. The youth training allowance is an essential part of the youth training initiative, which was announced as part of the white paper on employment and growth. The youth training initiative provides intensive case management, giving clients the assistance of a specific case manager in the search for work, training or education opportunities; a labour market or vocational training program placement for those who remain unemployed six months after registering; and income support by way of the youth training allowance, which is the subject of the present bill.

The government has given DEET the policy responsibility for the youth training initiative and so for the youth training allowance as part of this. This new arrangement will lead to greater emphasis than previously on income support as integrated into a process leading to employment or employment related outcomes. It will also involve increased cooperation and program delivery between the relevant departments. The new closer administrative arrangements are reflected already in moves to have a common definition of the criteria for homelessness and the proposal to have one appeals tribunal, the Social Security Appeals Tribunal, to review appeals concerning social security payments, youth training allowance and student assistance payments.

However, clients will find that the delivery of the youth training allowance will be the same as for the jobsearch allowance. The Department of Social Security will be the payment agency handling grants, ongoing payments matters and benefits control aspects. The Department of Employment, Education and Training will handle labour market matters such as labour market assessment and labour market program placements.

Senator Troeth and Senator Bell also referred to comments by the Welfare Rights Centre that the proposed legislation is unduly complex and that the youth training allowance should have been established by amending the Social Security Act rather than the Student Assistance Act. The placement of the youth training allowance in DEET legislation reflects the view that the youth training initiative is best located in the employment, education and training portfolio.

It is simplistic to suggest that all income support legislation should be placed in the Social Security Act. There is a range of legislation dealing with income maintenance located in different portfolios. Income for students is already in legislation in the employment, education and training portfolio. Income support for farm households is in the primary industry portfolio. Health care cards are covered under legislation in the health and human services portfolio. In any event, lawyers and others who give legal advice to young people about income support would already have to have access to both the Social Security Act and the Student Assistance Act.

There were NUS concerns that departmental officers will be appointed to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. Already DSS officers are appointed to the SSAT. Departmental members are appointed because of their knowledge of departmental operations. Their role is to draw the tribunal's attention to relevant legislation and matters impinging under departmental administration. They are on full-time secondment to the tribunal and are regarded as being on leave without pay from the Australian Public Service for the duration of their appointment.

It is important to note that DEET staff who may be appointed to the tribunal compete on merit. If successful, they will not represent DEET but must act impartially. In discussions between the NUS and the minister, the NUS agreed that it would monitor the role of DEET officers and report back to the minister if it considered that there were problems.

Concerns by NUS about the differential between the Department of Social Security student assistant waivers were raised with the government. The briefing I have is that the intention was that the restructuring of the appeal provisions should be cost neutral. However, the government has given the NUS an undertaking that we will look at this issue in the budget context.

In summary, the government appreciates the comments made by the NUS. Discussions between the minister and the NUS have resolved concerns raised by the NUS to its satisfaction. As far as the government is concerned, there are now no outstanding issues between the NUS and the government on these issues. Therefore, the government believes that it has given proper and lengthy consultation to the community. We have heard those views, responded accordingly, and given those undertakings which are now in the second reading reply that I have just given.

Therefore, we believe that the amendments to be moved by Senator Margetts are not supported, especially the second reading amendment she has just explained. We do not see the need to have a report back date by the end of 1995, I think it was—

TALK.START.PARA: —The first day of sitting in 1996.
—The beginning of 1996.

—We do not believe that is necessary. We would imagine that, if there are any concerns in the community on the administration in this area, there are plenty of appropriate opportunities for Senator Margetts and other senators to raise these issues in the parliament, at question time, at the estimates committees as well as at the appropriate standing committee.

PARA.TAB: Knowing the interest that Senator Margetts and others in the community have in these areas, these issues will be aired, as they ought to be, in the Senate and in the estimates committees long before the first sitting day in 1996 comes round. I therefore commend the bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to indicate on behalf of the coalition that we will not be supporting Senator Margetts's amendment. Although the possible criticisms that I made of the amalgamation of these two departments still stand, I think the coalition would want to wait to see the results of that amalgamated administration. At this stage, we would not want to commit the Senate to such a long-term review when some aspects of employment and training may well have changed over that intervening period. Much as I hate to agree with Senator Schacht, there will be ample opportunity for senators to review that whole process during that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the minister to explain why the government has found it necessary to bring 25 pages of amendments to its own legislation into the chamber at this time. Then he might explain what they are all about.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government amendments cover the following matters: to modify the assets test in cases where a family farm is located in an area extremely affected by drought; the assets test will not apply where a young person has a parent or partner who receives the new drought relief payment; the assets test will not apply to farm assets located in areas affected by extreme drought. This will continue for six months after the drought breaks. The timing of the drought relief package meant that it was not possible for these measures to be included in the main bill when it was being drafted.

PARA.TAB: The amendments also provide that appeals relating to student assistance schemes will be heard by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. This is the tribunal that will hear youth training allowance appeals. This decision was taken too late for this matter to be included in the drafting of the main bill.

The government amendments provide that if a person received a social security benefit at the independent rate other than by being homeless he or she will receive the independent rate of youth training allowance. This is a minor but important consequential amendment and it was overlooked in the preparation of the main bill. Finally, the government amendments provide that where the youth training allowance includes an ancillary payment that is part of formal training assistance, that payment has to be made out of the appropriation for formal training assistance and not from the youth training allowance appropriation. I presume Senator Hill is not opposing the drought relief amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am having trouble finding them. The minister might point them out.
—They were circulated yesterday.

—Will the minister point out the relevant clauses to me in these 25 pages that deal with drought. If he wants to, he can start on page 1 and explain to me why it is necessary to change the definition of `officer'. We will work through them clause by clause. Furthermore, the minister might explain to the chamber why government members of the Senate committee were not prepared to consider them within the committee, which would have been the sensible way of dealing with the matter.
—It was not necessary.
—Senator Zakharov thinks this is good process, does she—dumping 25 pages of amendments at the last minute.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Hill does not want drought relief going to farming families, that is fine. If that is what Senator Hill is really on about, if he wants to knock off the drought relief for farming families, fine. We will have him on the record for that and we will use it very usefully.
—Very stupid. Explain to us what the definition of `officer' means.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the reason for these changes in definition interpretation is that there has been a change to the appeals process. It has changed from one tribunal, the Student Assistance Review Tribunal, to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. That is a structural change and has meant that a number of consequential changes are required in the bill.
—As that change was in the principal bill, why were the consequential changes not included as well?
—They are in the amendments.
—They are not in the last lot of amendments.
—They are the ones that, I am informed, were circulated yesterday.
—Would you explain to me why it is necessary to say that the definition of an officer includes `a person who has been such a person'?
—I am advised that the definition is a rewriting of the existing definition to make it more comprehensive for the Social Security Appeals Tribunal.
—What do you mean by `more comprehensive'?
—I have been advised that page 4 of the supplementary explanatory memorandum that I have just tabled explains subclause 5(1).
—It is not on my page 4.
—Under `Notes on Clauses, Amendment Number 1', it is stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Subclause 5(1) would be amended to substitute the definition of `officer' to provide that an officer—

TALK.START.PARA: —Page 5.

—Mine is on page 4. There are two memorandums. I think the one Senator Hill is reading from goes to page 8 and the one I am reading from goes to page 27—the thicker one. You are reading from the `Requests for amendments to be moved on behalf of the Government'; I am reading from `Amendments and new clauses to be moved on behalf of the Government'.
—I have not been given that one.
—It was tabled.
—You said it was necessary to have a more comprehensive definition of `officer'. Could you explain to me why it is necessary—
—I will read from the memorandum. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Subclause 5(1) would be amended to substitute the definition of `officer' to provide that an officer for the purposes of youth training allowance and student assistance would refer to a person performing duties or exercising powers or functions under this legislation. For the purposes of the confidentiality provisions contained in Division 3 of Part 10, the definition would extend to all persons in the first category and persons who have been appointed or employed and who may have performed services for the Commonwealth and accessed information relating to people under this legislation.
It goes on to say:
Subclause 5(1) would be amended by omitting the definitions of `authorised person' and `prescribed officer'. Subclause 5(1) would be further amended by inserting the following definitions:
`protected information' which will encompass information held about a person in the records of the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the Department of Social Security;

`student assistance benefit' which defines a student assistance benefit to mean a payment under the AUSTUDY scheme, the Student Financial Supplement Scheme, or a current or former special educational scheme.
I think the first paragraph, 5(1), of the memorandum explains why we have changed the definition.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether we could seek some clarification. There seem to be a series of supplementary explanatory memoranda that the government has floating around today. Some seem to relate to amendments for new clauses, and some seem to relate to requests for amendments to be moved on behalf of the government. I understand that there are three separate documents that the government has circulated in the form of explanatory memoranda in relation to this matter. Would the minister please explain what each relates to?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I advise the committee that I was given leave to table four documents: two were amendments to be moved on behalf of the government and two were requests for amendments to be moved on behalf of the government. We are dealing with two separate bills in this package.
—I cannot find the drought part in what we are debating. So the minister might explain to me exactly where I should find it, seeing that he has said that that is what it is all about.

SPEECH.PARA: The second amendment would make an amendment to assist families with farms located in areas extremely affected by drought. The assets test will not apply in respect of a person to include farm assets of that person or that person's family where a drought relief exceptional circumstances certificate has been issued in respect of the person or a member of the person's family.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not on my page 8.
