TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That progress be reported.

SPEECH.PARA: If I am successful, I will then move that the bill be referred back to the relevant Senate legislation committee in order that it might consider the dozens of amendments that the government has put forward, which have not gone through the normal party processes. This will, therefore, give the chamber an opportunity to process the matter in an orderly and sensible way because it certainly cannot be dealt with that way in here today.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I want to make a comment on the suggestion. This legislation has to be in place by 1 January. Clearly, I suspect there are a lot of people in a large area of New South Wales and Queensland who want this legislation to go through.

PARA.TAB: I take the point of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill). I am not unreasonable on these matters. We could have progress reported for a period, and the bill not referred to a committee, in order for the opposition and the other minority parties to have a look at the detail of the amendments. We could then deal with it later today or this week. To refer it off to a committee without a guarantee that it will be back here to be debated and passed before 1 January would be catastrophic, particularly for the drought relief part of it. Also, we want the youth training allowance to operate from 1 January, so the bill has to be carried by the end of this parliamentary session, which is the end of next week. If Senator Hill is willing to move that progress be reported so that—

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)—The question will be that progress be reported. Once it is reported, if the Senate so wishes some resolution can be moved after that. But we can just take it at this stage that progress be reported.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—From the coalition's point of view, we have undertaken that certain pieces of legislation will be dealt with in the Senate this session. That includes this bill. We have no desire to hold up any drought legislation, and the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) knows that. But there must be some orderly processing of legislation within the chamber, otherwise the chamber might as well not exist.

PARA.TAB: What has been presented to us today is a total shambles. The minister does not even know how many explanatory memoranda he has. There are amendments upon amendments to the bill, and that is not the way in which we can get any orderly or sensible debate. I cannot understand why the committee that Senator Schacht controls declined to do the job that the committee was set up to do. Senator Schacht may have an explanation for that, but that structure was put in place to avoid this sort of situation. It was put in place to try to ensure better processing of legislation. Senator Schacht seems to just disregard that. I think he just wishes this chamber to be nothing more than a rubber stamp of the executive. There are some of us in this place who are not prepared to behave that way.

So we will have a discussion—I guess it can be an informal discussion afterwards—as to whether the bill goes back to the committee, whether we have reasonable time to consider the amendments and whether we wish to take them through normal party processes. I am quite happy for that debate to be held, if others are, in an informal way. But it would be a total waste of time for us to work through this clause by clause today when the minister obviously does not know what it is about. We are not in a position to make a reasoned decision on which of these amendments to amendments we will support.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I have been informed by my officers that Senator Troeth received a briefing about these amendments yesterday. I understand that Senator Hill was not briefed, so I appreciate that he may not be fully up to date. I also appreciate that these are extensive amendments. But they are not what we would consider controversial amendments, particularly those relating to drought relief.
—You didn't offer a briefing to us.

—I am not unreasonable. I have not been unreasonable to Senator Hill. I accept that we should report progress. I will have an informal discussion with Senator Hill and Senator Troeth, and with the other parties, about when we will report back. I do not think it is necessary for this to go off to the committee when there is no controversy involved with the amendments. We have to get this through by the end of next week. I accept Senator Hill's commitment that no-one wants to hold up the drought relief package. So, provided we report progress, we will have an informal discussion so that everyone, including the minority parties, will have a chance over the next day or so to discuss the contents of the government amendments. This matter could then be back on the Notice Paper by, say, Wednesday afternoon or Thursday, or certainly by the end of the week.

PARA.TAB: The government will accept that informal arrangement. Even though we think these are not controversial amendments, I accept that Senator Hill wants to look at the detail of the explanatory memorandum that he has not seen, at the order, and so on. I accept that, but I strongly resist going back to the committee because there is just a chance that this will slip through the cracks and we will not get back in time for it to be carried. It must be in place by 1 January.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Obviously, the Australian Democrats would not like to see any part of this bill forestalled by procedural problems. That is not because we accept as a threat that the drought package could be challenged. I think Senator Schacht would acknowledge that the there is unanimous support for the package, the concept behind it and the idea that it be implemented as soon as possible. We would certainly not want to impede its progress.

PARA.TAB: However, the situation here demonstrates the arrogance of the government in releasing the youth training initiative, with all its bells and whistles, only last week with the assumption that the Senate would toe the line. The situation demonstrates the ridiculousness of any process that would allow that to happen.

I was fortunate enough to have a briefing offered to me. Because I was at a committee meeting, I was not able to attend. My researcher had to bear the brunt of that briefing—but at least it was offered. My officer was left with the impression that this is not a contentious set of amendments and that the concerns of at least one lobby group, the NUS, had been addressed in the main. But that is not the point.

The point is that, having done that, the government assumed that which should have been open for negotiation and should have been dependent upon the Senate's affirmative resolution. The Democrats support reporting progress. There is a great danger that, if we do not, we will end up in confusion and make mistakes which will have dire consequences for the whole concept of this bill and for the operation of the measures designed to assist students, their parents and the community. We have to get it right, but the process engaged in so far has not led easily to finding a path. I support the idea of reporting progress.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The Greens also support the move to report progress at this stage. When we arrived here today, there were amendments that had not been circulated.
—Amendments were circulated. The explanatory memorandums were not circulated.
—There were Democrat amendments which, at that stage, had not been circulated.
—The government's amendments had been.

—Yes, but there were other amendments which other parties had not had a chance to look at at that stage. We need to give this bill due consideration. It is all very well rushing through a bill, but we have to make decisions that we all have to live with. If we do not want a future legislative program that spends a great deal of time fixing up mistakes that any of us could make if we do not look at the consequences carefully, we have to spend the time that is necessary to make decisions right now. I agree to the idea of at least allowing time for the various parties to see what each other's amendments are saying and to make the best decision that we can make on this bill.

PARA.TAB: Progress reported.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I want to emphasise that the coalition recognises the need to provide assistance to Cambodia. I fully acknowledge that a stable Cambodia is important for the security of the region, and Australia has an interest in supporting that security. That said, the coalition is very eager to ensure that Australian aid to Cambodia is focused in a very specific way. We do not, in any way, support the provision of lethal military assistance to Cambodia. The current problems in that country will not be ameliorated by the provision of military equipment or ammunition. Indeed, it is quite possible that the provision of Australian military hardware and ammunition would only complicate the strife in Cambodia. We know that it is reported that Thailand is not happy at the prospect of any military assistance being given to Cambodia.

PARA.TAB: I point out also that our other ASEAN neighbours have not exactly been rushing in to provide military aid themselves. Indeed, it is interesting to note in the ministers' press release—this is a very wishy-washy statement, I suggest—that:

SPEECH.PARA: Indonesia and Malaysia have also indicated they are prepared to provide training assistance.

There are no details. There is no announcement from Indonesia and Malaysia. We are not told what they have indicated they are prepared to provide or when, or whether it will be contingent upon something else happening. That is not very impressive. From the contact I have had with defence people from ASEAN countries, I know that the view of their governments is that economic assistance is of some value to Cambodia and military aid could well be counterproductive.

PARA.TAB: So the Australian government has been rushing in to perhaps keep Gareth Evans and his baby going, but the rest of the region has not been leading the way. It is intriguing that since last July we seem to have been spending time canvassing support to try to get other nations to come in with us—of course, this has not been announced in this statement.

I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that a paper which was released recently by the Australian Defence Studies Centre pointed out that there are a number of compelling reasons to categorically rule out the supply of lethal aid to Cambodia. Those reasons included: that civil aid measures would be more effective in combating the Khmer Rouge; that the Royal Cambodian Armed Forces do not appear sufficiently competent to defeat the Khmer Rouge in battle; that there is little confidence that the RCAF will respect human rights; that lethal aid would also give rise to corruption and possible onward sales of Australian weapons and equipment to the Khmer Rouge; and that lethal assistance appears to be unnecessary given that there is adequate material already in Cambodia. In fact, only this week our ambassador in Cambodia was reported as having said that the most valuable aid for Cambodia is civil aid.

On page 12 of the statement the ministers refer to Australian aid. They spell out the details of the civil development aid commitment, which is $92 million over the next four years. Our aid program was ranked sixth in 1993 after France, the United States, Sweden and the Netherlands. The aims of that program are to promote good governance, foster political and social stability, provide for poverty alleviation, and promote sustainable economic progress and human resource development—all worthy of achievement and certainly worth trying for. I believe that our best hope is to give this sort of assistance to Cambodia for its long-term future.

We believe that a more acceptable military aid approach to Cambodia should focus on the provision of training with a guarantee that Australia will not become involved in combat operations there. I am very concerned about two reports in today's newspapers. There is an article in the Sydney Morning Herald by David Lague and another in the Age by Karen Middleton, both of which appear to have been written based on briefings that they had received. Both of those articles are very similar in tone. One article states:

It is believed fewer than 10 Australian military personnel will now be sent to train battalions in Cambodia. Sources said the mode of training was likely to be similar to Australian-run training in Vietnam but that Cambodian battalions would not be sent out on operational exercises in areas where they are likely to encounter the Khmer Rouge.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose that is a godsend. The only thing is that their job is to encounter the Khmer Rouge, I would have thought. The other article states:

PARA.TAB: The Army's training specialists would decide how many instructors were needed after designing a training program for the Cambodians. The Army will use a similar system to that used during the Vietnam War, when instructors worked closely with South Vietnamese units to improve their ability to fight a counter-insurgency war.

SPEECH.PARA: The article went on to say:

PARA.TAB: In Vietnam, Australian advisers and instructors played key roles in assisting the South Vietnamese on operations and the danger of this happening in Cambodia has alarmed the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: You betcha! It has. Surely to goodness, this country can learn lessons from history. Gareth Evans, for one, was marching in the streets of Australia protesting about sending young men to the killing fields in Vietnam. Yet somebody is countenancing—because these briefings appear to have occurred to at least two defence journalists—that the training proposed is comparable to the training role of those advisers of the AATV in the early days in Vietnam. I am informed that that is not the case. But somebody has been briefing defence journalists. I say to the government now, in the Senate, in the parliament of Australia, that the opposition will be relying on the commitments given by the government today and we will be holding the government accountable. This is not to be a swamp into which young Australians are dragged with early assurances that that is the only assistance—and then the reality becomes very different later on.

PARA.TAB: We believe that Australia's aid should focus on the provision of resources to train RCAF personnel in mine clearance. We acknowledge that some work has been done already. But less than half of one per cent of the mines in Cambodia have been cleared, although there has been substantial input from other countries as well as Australia. Until such time as the farming land in Cambodia is cleared, the economy has no hope of getting up and running again. If we want to help Cambodians, it is vitally important that we help them clear their mines. Resources can also be appropriately allocated to assist the RCAF in an appropriate reform plan for their forces.

It is also appropriate that we should bring RCAF officers to Australia for training. It is practical. They learn by example. It is less likely to involve our own troops in a dangerous and very unstable environment. By bringing them back here, they can see what happens in another country where an army is subject to a democratic government and where our army is not corrupt.

Having outlined the forms of assistance we believe Australia could provide to Cambodia, it is also time to point out that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) should get together and give the Australian parliament and people some explanation of Australia's defence and security interests in Cambodia. While this statement released today goes some way towards establishing the reason for Australia's provision of assistance, I believe the defence minister at least should provide a more in-depth account of how the security situation in Cambodia is relevant to Australia's security.

The six lines which outline our national interests in providing assistance to Cambodia are inadequate. Can we seriously expect that the Australian parliament and people should be fobbed off with such cursory treatment of such a vital issue? Does the government believe that the instability in Cambodia represents a possible threat to Australia and its people? Does Labor secretly harbour fear of a domino effect resulting from the strife in Cambodia? I am old enough to remember Labor scoffing at the domino theory before, but that can be the only explanation, surely, for it saying that our national security interests are involved in Cambodia and that there is potentially a threat to Australia and its people.

When we have a look at the statement, it is interesting to see what a great deal of obviously defence initiated information and detail there is on the assessment of the Khmer Rouge. Compare that with what I presume is the foreign affairs department's assessment and its lack of detail on our national interest and it highlights the reason why I say we have not been given a proper assessment; and the Australian people deserve better.

I would also like the government to clarify the somewhat ambiguous statement contained in paragraph 5 of the press release that outlines the nature of the Australian aid package. What does the government mean by saying, `Some equipment will also be provided for use in training'? It could mean anything. I am informed that this means webbing and training aids, all of which, I am sure, the Khmer Rouge will be truly grateful for. But the statement is not specific and it leaves the government's options open in the future to change the equipment that it currently claims it is intending to send. I want that detail on the public record.

Why has the government decided not to increase the level of assistance for mine clearance when that is of such importance to the future economic well-being of Cambodians? The statement pays almost no attention to the corruption that is rife in the RCAF or, for that matter, in the government. It mentions it once in passing. Why is this? It is an unfortunate fact that the government wishes to ignore this, presumably, as it seeks to assist in the rehabilitation of the RCAF. But if Australia is to help with the reform, surely this matter needs to be dealt with in greater detail by the government. It needs to be acknowledged because it is basic to the problem.

The coalition also wants to know where most of Australia's in-country assistance will be located in Cambodia. The assessment in the statement about the possible danger to ADF personnel is serious and should be treated seriously. Can the Australian government give the parliament the assurance that the ADF personnel on the ground in Cambodia will be adequately protected by the RCAF? We do not really have much justification for being confident in the ability of RCAF personnel to defend our troops sent there.

Today's statement argues that the Khmer Rouge is not likely to expand its areas of control and influence over the long term. Elsewhere in the paper there is an argument that the strength of the Khmer Rouge combat force is in the decline with the numbers being 8,000 to 10,000 in the field, with 5,000 of these being hard-core fighters. I remind the government that some 30,000 guerillas in Greece were able to tie up eight divisions of crack German troops for much of the Second World War. Closer to home, 6,000 guerillas were able to tie up 300,000 British, Australian and New Zealand forces, police and home guard forces, during the Malayan emergency for more than 10 years. They were all well trained.

In Malaya there was the incomparable advantage of having a democratic system of government, a well ordered society, good infrastructure and villagers prevented from resupplying the terrorists. None of that can be said to be the case in Cambodia; therefore, the prospects for the RCAF in dealing with the guerillas is that much worse. Although the Khmer Rouge may be declining in numbers, it still has a greater potential for war than this report admits.

I draw the Senate's attention to some of the statements about the current military situation which I think should be highlighted. The government acknowledges that the Khmer Rouge: . . . poses a severe security problem for the government and this problem is likely to continue in one form or another unless the Royal Cambodian Armed Forces (RCAF) are made more effective.

SPEECH.PARA: A heightened guerilla campaign . . . in the coming dry season cannot be ruled out. This is following an established pattern of skirmishing, guerilla hit-and-run tactics and terrorist attacks. This is common in guerilla wars. The Khmer Rouge is capable of conducting this sort of campaign for some years. It aims to regain sole power by destabilising—politically, economically and militarily—through protracted insurgency. It is conducting a campaign to damage infrastructure, harass RCAF forces and discourage economic development to raise revenue through trade in timber and gems and through bandit activity, including hostage-taking, levying illegal taxes and making demands for protection money.

That was all going on when I was there in 1992. Nothing in that sense has changed. The numbers of hard-core Khmer Rouge may have diminished, but they can still mount this sort of guerilla campaign, and they can do it for a long time to come.

PARA.TAB: We are told that the military activity is concentrated in certain rural areas and that it is infiltrating areas that it was not in before. There is also increasing activity in the Siem Reap province. I remind honourable senators that that is the area where most overseas tourists visit. If they go nowhere else, they try to go to Angkor Wat. That tourist revenue is vitally important for the economic wellbeing of the country.

The government acknowledges that a hard core will inevitably remain and is unlikely to defect or be eradicated other than by military means. The statement also notes that the Khmer Rouge is attempting to counter its losses by using violence and intimidation to obtain forced labour and military reinforcements or porters for the coming dry season. Some incidences of this have been detailed in the statement. The conclusion in the statement notes that the tactics probably indicate that the Khmer Rouge is becoming more desperate. I would dispute that. The Khmer Rouge may well be wanting to get more villagers in to act as bearers and porters, but it also means that it is very effective when it can point to the violence and the terrorism it has already perpetrated. It becomes more effective through fear. We should not write off the Khmer Rouge simply by saying it is becoming more desperate. We should recognise that, if it is more desperate, the measures that it is taking have the potential to make it even more powerful through the control that it will have over the villages.

We have had the up and down situation of the Minister for Foreign Affairs as to whether there is any support across the Thai border. Most of the ASEAN states would acknowledge that support across the Thai border has been going on not just in recent times but historically. A common race of people straddles that border. People have been toing-and-froing across that border for centuries. It also happens to be in the interests of some people to have instability on the other side of the border.

I am not suggesting that it is the Thai government. I presume that the minister is not claiming that it is the Thai government. But I think it is unrealistic to think that it will ever be completely controlled, and therein lies the danger. Trading across the border in timber and gems continues to put resources into the hands of the Khmer Rouge, just as the Vietcong was able to keep being resupplied from the north. Those are the realities that we have to face. As I said, we are prepared to support the measures that have been spelled out in the statement today, but with the provisos and the questions which I have put on the public record which do deserve serious answer.

I am pleased to read that the RCAF is to be downsized and rationalised. I believe it is imperative that the Cambodian defence budget should account for much less than the staggering 28 per cent of the total Cambodian budget that it currently occupies. That is one more reason why corruption should have been mentioned. Corruption is one of the root causes for 28 per cent of the Cambodian budget being spent on defence, the troops not being paid and our having to help pay to demobilise the soldiers. That 28 per cent of the budget should not need to be spent on defence. If it was not going into some of the wrong pockets, it would not need to be. If it was not going into some of the wrong pockets, the soldiers would be paid. The Australian taxpayer has been spending enough on making our own servicemen redundant. I wonder why Cambodia cannot organise itself better to demobilise its own soldiers. We know why. It is because of corruption.

Defence has grabbed back some of the control over this debate, and I am glad to see that. Some reality does show up in this statement as to the assessment of the military situation and the position of the Khmer Rouge. We support the government's statement but questions which are not answered in this statement still need to be answered for us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats also agree that Cambodia is in immediate need of Australian aid, most particularly in the form of civil aid. We are very pleased to see that that is provided for in this statement. We do not accept—we are pleased that neither does the government nor the opposition—that the provision of lethal materiel is acceptable in these circumstances or in most circumstances; it is not.

PARA.TAB: We also agree with the government's emphasis on training and with its assurance that no Australian personnel will be involved in any support or advisory role during any military offensives which might take place in Cambodia. In recent months, there has been a great deal of debate on the benefits or otherwise of Australia providing additional military aid to Cambodia and whether this aid should take the form of training or whether it should include military equipment as well. This debate has intensified as a result of clear evidence being presented of the menacing presence of the Khmer Rouge in the Cambodian countryside and the danger posed by its continued attacks on all aspects of the democratically elected Cambodian government.

For many Australians, the problems posed by the Khmer Rouge activities became a significant focal point during the recent kidnapping and subsequent murders of several hostages, including Australians. These events brought home to all of us that the Khmer Rouge is a totally brutal and criminal group—most of them I imagine are not very sane either—whose continued presence should no longer be tolerated by the international community.

Cambodia is entirely justified in requesting additional defence assistance from a number of nations, including Australia, particularly as this country has already played such a vital role in the implementation of the UN peace plan and also because of our existing involvement in Cambodia, particularly in the form of mine clearance and the installation of an updated and effective military communications system. It is perhaps understandable that, given the way the Cambodian armed forces were pulled together from very disparate forces, certain problems would have been encountered in its attempts to deal with the Khmer Rouge.

We have to remember that the Royal Cambodian Armed Forces are not the same as the Australian Defence Force. We are very lucky in this country. We probably have one of the most professional defence forces in the world. When we look at where the Cambodian defence force came from—not very long ago either—we cannot imagine that it would be anywhere near the standard we expect.

However, the obvious failure of the Cambodian military in effectively dealing with the Khmer Rouge has probably been exacerbated by both the political and economic problems which the emerging Cambodian democracy has had to grapple with. Unfortunately, the Khmer Rouge's continued presence has not been helped by the relatively strong economic base, supported as it is—and it certainly still is—by an extremely lucrative trade in timber and gemstones across the country's borders, including the Thai border.

The Democrats have always believed that if it were possible to cut off its substantial economic power base then the international community would stand a far better chance of finally seeing an end to the Khmer Rouge. Certainly, recent comments by various Thai government representatives represent a very hopeful sign that Thailand has been moving to cut off the economic relationships and the lines of support which have effectively kept the Khmer Rouge in business in recent years.

As Senator Newman said, nobody in this chamber has ever said that the Thai government was the one doing that. Nobody believed it a couple of weeks ago and they do not believe it now. But there have been in the recent past some very unscrupulous people on the Thai border keeping the Khmer Rouge in business with timber and gems.

Given the strength of Thailand's assurances on this issue in recent months, especially since the remarks of Senator Gareth Evans, the Democrats hope that the international community will shortly be witnessing the benefits of Thailand's forceful anti-Khmer Rouge strategy delivering results. The Democrats are especially encouraged by the government's obvious commitment in today's announcement that Australia remains absolutely committed to the provision of development aid to Cambodia over a significant period.

The international community needs to be reminded that long lasting peace in Cambodia can be brought about only with a continued and substantial development and aid commitment from the international donor community. Cambodia is in urgent need of development assistance, particularly in the three primary aid areas of health, education and rural development. We welcome the size of Australia's aid package to Cambodia in the form of $92 million over the next four years.

It is clear that the Royal Cambodian Armed Forces are in a less than satisfactory state and obviously not in a position to effectively deal with the threat posed by the Khmer Rouge. I was a bit surprised to hear Senator Newman say that the assessment of the strength and background of the Khmer Rouge contained in this document was apparently not what the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade had been telling her. It is pretty much what it had been telling me.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say that. You have it wrong.

—I am very pleased to hear Senator Newman say that she did not say that, because the department has been telling me these sorts of things. This is the assessment that the department of foreign affairs has given me in briefings over the years. I think the department of foreign affairs is on top of this matter. This is what it has been telling me for a substantial amount of time. I am pleased to see that this document is now public and is not just being given to people in briefings. It is a useful document, and it is one that I think can be used very successfully in now planning what we will do in the future.

PARA.TAB: The basic problem in relation to the Khmer Rouge—this is what I said to Senator Evans when I got back from Cambodia; I was there at about the same time as Senator Newman was there in 1992—is set out in paragraph 20 of the document. It says that the Khmer Rouge:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . may also believe that their advantage lies in a long campaign of guerilla warfare to wear down the government, constrain economic development, deter foreign investors and donors, and foment insecurity—with the aim of leaving the government no alternative, if peace is to be obtained, other than to offer the KR a power-sharing role.

I am still sure that that is what is going on in the heads of Khmer Rouge members. In the end, the Khmer Rouge still wants exclusive power, and some members of it still think they can get it. That is a very sad reflection. They are not going to give up if they think they have any chance of being successful in that. I do not think any of us think that they can be successful in that if the Cambodian government and particularly the Cambodian military are given a chance to actually look after themselves and stop this.

PARA.TAB: We do have a responsibility to our neighbours to ensure as far as we can that they can live in peace and security. The government's response to this problem is an appropriate one. We welcome today's announcement. We believe that the government has struck an appropriate balance in the measures contained here—measures which, in the long term, should ensure positive outcomes for the Cambodian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —`The Khmer Rouge problem is bound to continue in one form or another until either a political or military solution is found.' That was stated by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans, in a letter to the Sydney Morning Herald on 14 May this year. I will read it again: `The Khmer Rouge problem is bound to continue in one form or another until either a political or military solution is found.' That trite, banal statement typifies the approach of the government to the complexities of Cambodia.

PARA.TAB: Today we are asked for a further escalation in funding to support the Australian military aid program in Cambodia. What is not recognised is that we are already spending $25.5 million per year. There is a program of $92 million starting this financial year in civilian aid. There is $3 million under the military aid program. And to that we have today added another $5 million. There is something like $32 million going to Cambodia this year. The question that must be asked is: what is Australia's responsibility to Cambodia? Senator Evans answers that in the first paragraph of his statement today:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . our national interest in removing Cambodia as a source of regional instability and tension; our national interest, as a good international citizen, in relieving to the extent possible the enormous humanitarian problems posed by continuing insurgency in Cambodia; and our national interest in facilitating Cambodia's—and Indochina's—economic and political reintegration into regional and international affairs.

They are all good and laudable reasons, but they are irrelevant, in one sense, until we assign some priority to Australia's involvement in those matters. We have to recognise that Australia has limited resources and, thanks to this government, we are hugely in debt ourselves and almost in need of an aid program. So we have to set priorities.

PARA.TAB: This year this government is giving $66.2 million to Indonesia; $50.4 million to Vietnam; $40.3 million to the Philippines; and now this $30-odd million to Cambodia. The great majority of Australians do not agree with those being our priorities. They think that we have a greater relationship with, and an obligation to, the nations in our near region, principally Papua New Guinea, which the foreign minister does not want to recognise exists. The government has consistently run down the long-term funding obligations we have to that country and to the South Pacific and the South West Pacific areas. They are just a black hole when it comes to policy and interest from this government. Of course, we have an interest in doing things for ourselves and in creating some opportunities to get the nearly one million unemployed off the street.

Before I deal with Australian policy in respect of Cambodia, a brief history of this state is important. Cambodia is a very unfortunate buffer state between two great countries, Vietnam and Thailand, and they have fought over Cambodia for most of the last millennium. In recent history there was the government of Prince Norodom Sihanouk from 1953 to 1970. From 1970 to 1975 there was the Lon Nol regime. From 1975 to 1979 there was the Khmer Rouge regime, controlled by Pol Pot, which was truly one of the most terrible regimes in history. From 1979 to 1989 there was the invasion by Vietnam of Cambodia. From 1989 to 1992 there was SOC and the successors to SOC after the election, the coalition government of FUNCINPEC and CPP as SOC has become.

In essence, Australian policy on Cambodia prior to the Paris agreement has been characterised by undue optimism. We have still not reached a hard-headed, pragmatic appreciation of the situation in the country. When the Paris agreement was signed, we made a large contribution to UNTAC, which was the most expensive operation ever that the UN has entered into, costing over $A3 billion. Australia's contribution to that was honourable and very effective in bringing about the outcomes that it did. Since the election in Cambodia, Australian policy has been directed towards a face saving exercise for the wrong appreciations we made at the outset. It is quite true that we do not have any pragmatic policy in this country. We have a policy vacuum in relation to the Khmer Rouge.

The opposition was always very uneasy about these flaws in the policy, and we said so on the opportunities that were provided to us from 1990 onwards. Post-election we have been very concerned about this vacuum in the government's approach to a country in which it has taken a very keen interest. The Khmer Rouge is very important factor; it is probably the most important factor in Cambodian affairs. What we are faced with today is a rather simplistic view that if, somehow or other, we fixed up the royal Cambodian army, we would eliminate the Khmer Rouge. Nothing could be further from the truth.

I am not a defender of the Khmer Rouge at all. I think it is one of the most terrible regimes we have seen on the face of the earth. In four years, when running the country, it killed between one to two million people. Anyone who had any education at all was just taken out and slaughtered. If one had glasses, it was a sign that one was educated. If one had travelled overseas, if one had relatives overseas, one was anti-Cambodian, so one was taken out and slaughtered. We had this insane regime which tried to go back to an early primitive agricultural economy.

In 1979, the Vietnamese moved in and took on the Khmer Rouge. The Vietnamese were the victors of the war in Vietnam. They were very skilled and understood completely guerrilla warfare. They were well led and well trained. In 10 years the Vietnamese army had nearly 55,000 soldiers killed. The Khmer Rouge troops killed and wounded in the order of a quarter of a million Vietnamese troops. They could not beat the Khmer Rouge in 10 years. The scale of losses of the Vietnamese army was comparable to the American losses in Vietnam. To say that the Khmer Rouge is an irrelevant force within the context of Cambodian affairs is quite wrong.

I will accept that today, five years on from the Paris agreements, the Khmer Rouge is very different. I am prepared to accept the figure that their strength is only between 8,000 to 10,000 troops at present. But it is well resourced. It has plenty of money, plenty of arms and plenty of munitions. It is well disciplined and well trained. It is prepared to pursue the goal that it has always had of running the country. There has to be some strategy put in place to deal with this evil force in Cambodia.

On the other side, the Cambodian army is clearly underpaid, and some of it is not paid at all. It is undisciplined and untrained. It is said to be short of some military materiel. I am not sure of that because I think there is quite a bit of materiel around Cambodia. The other great problem that the Cambodian army suffers from is that it is a melding of three traditional enemies. After the election and the formation of the coalition government, those armies came together.

There is no question that, as Senator Newman said, it needs to be restructured, it needs to be disciplined, its training needs to be improved and it needs some materiel. Most important of all of those is the inculcation of discipline and obedience within the troops. While courage, technical skill and skill at arms are fundamental and important assets of an army, the most important asset of an army is obedience, because without obedience it is a rabble. The RCAF is a long way from being a trained obedient force at the present time. But it is no good putting effort into the army when the government in place is as incompetent and inadequate as the Cambodian government is at the present time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you read paragraph 36?

—In a nutshell, it is weak, indecisive, incompetent and corrupt. Senator Evans by way of interjection says that that is in his paper. That is perfectly true, but he does not draw any conclusions from that. He does not go on and suggest programs which will deal with the fundamental problem.

PARA.TAB: Soldiers will not go out and fight for a government that they know is incompetent, inadequate and corrupt. A soldier's calling requires him to lay down his life for his country and no RCAF soldier at the present time thinks that that is a good idea given the present government in Phnom Penh. They are faced with Khmer Rouge troops who really will die for the cause. They believe in what they are doing, however terrible it might have been in the past. They are prepared to fight and die for the cause they believe in. We are just not going to get anywhere until we can inspire the RCAF soldiers by having a solid, honest administration behind them which they know is doing the best for the country.

The government has proposed that there be no lethal aid given to the RCAF in this venture. We on this side of the chamber support that entirely. It is very easy to make a simple division between advisers that go there to train and advisers that get involved in combat operations. In practice it does not work out that way. It is a very difficult line to enforce once we get involved in the training of the defence force of another country. We saw this very clearly with Vietnam.

The big difference between Vietnam and Cambodia was that Vietnam was a worthwhile cause. Without the involvement of Australia, America, Korea and all the other countries in Vietnam the whole stability of the South-East Asian area would not exist today. ASEAN would not exist and Thailand, Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia would not be the prosperous countries they are. The investment in the Vietnam war by Australia and its allies bought a breathing space to develop the democracies in South-East Asia. The same cannot be said about Cambodia.

The other point that I suppose Senator Evans is quite oblivious of is the fact that Australia has been involved in training Cambodian troops before. In the early 1970s in the Phuoc Tuy province some of the Lon Nol soldiers were brought across for training by the Australian forces. We on this side of the house are very opposed to Australians being involved in combat operations in Cambodia and we will maintain that vigilance relentlessly.

The other question I have to ask Senator Evans is: why so much money? We are committing $3 million already under the military aid program. We are going to add another $5 million to that, so that is $8 million. Given that we are only sending advisers, we do not have to buy arms or ammunition, pay for extensive travel costs or anything like that, I would have thought $8 million was a very large sum for a training program. I do not have any figures to be able to attribute costs for personnel, but just off the top of my head I would think that, for every $1 million spent, we could accommodate 30 Australian military advisers in a training role in Cambodia, given that most of what they will be doing will be instructional. So I would think $8 million should buy a very sizeable input into the training of the Cambodian army.

The difficulty is that, without good diplomatic backup, what are our soldiers going to do? It is all very well to put very capable instructors into the field, but if they are not supported by superior Cambodian officers who value and reinforce what they are doing, if they are not supported by the Cambodian government, then it all is in vain.

In a military sense, there are plenty of other things that can be done in Cambodia. The question of demining has been raised by all the speakers so far. The mine problem, anti-personnel mines in particular, in Cambodia is an acute problem. Large areas of the country cannot be used for agriculture because it is estimated there are somewhere between six million and 10 million AP mines in the country. No-one knows where they are. No maps were kept at the time and floods have washed the mines around. The dreadful morbidity and mortality of this is seen in the hospitals and rehabilitation centres around Phnom Penh and the other large towns. A great deal of work has to be done there.

A great deal needs to be done with educational programs in Cambodia. One of the consequences of the Pol Pot regime was the elimination of anyone with any education. As a consequence, the administration of the country is weak because not enough people have an adequate education. The whole of the administration needs beefing up. The standard of living in the country has to be raised. If those things are done, the effect of the Khmer Rouge will be limited because it will be marginalised.

We are not opposed to what is being proposed today. But we are very concerned that the government does not have a clear idea as to why it is doing it and where it wants to end up. We will be watching to make sure that it does not go into any adventures that will put Australian lives at risk in that very attractive but very poor country which, sadly, is going through one of the very worst pages of its history.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator MacGibbon has said, Cambodia is going through one of the worst stages of its history—a deplorable two decades of war, genocide and turmoil. I note and support the remarks of my colleagues who have commented on the announcement today. I join with them and Senator Bourne in commenting on the theme at the foundation of all those remarks—I will come to the details in a moment—which is to welcome the government's assistance for Cambodia and to welcome the Australian government's supplementation of its already existing social and economic aid to the people of Cambodia. The last page of the statement that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) has tabled says:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia will not give up on the Cambodian people.
That is a statement which I believe all senators support.

PARA.TAB: Where this minister and this government come in for criticism from my colleagues and from me is in their failure to maintain a consistent reporting to this parliament of the situation in Cambodia and their failure to give adequate detail about the matters this statement is about. We all agree that social and economic development is the best lifeline for Cambodia. Much of that will come from the hard work of the people of that country and will be assisted by appropriate development assistance to social and economic objectives.

Justice Michael Kirby has met with the human rights committee of this parliament. I have listened carefully to his reports. He is now a rapporteur to the UN Secretary-General with regard to the situation of human rights in Cambodia. What he observes is a mixed bag. There is some progress with regard to courts, the rule of law, and some health and other outcomes for women and children and indeed for all people. But there are deplorable transgressions of human rights in Cambodia, not least of which is corruption in the government and banditry in the countryside. Those serious problems also happen to involve government officials and members of the Cambodian armed forces—not just the guerillas in the countryside, as we all acknowledge. We acknowledge that there is a problem with the Khmer Rouge's abuse of the Cambodian people being one of the most ghastly records of abuse of people in any country at any time. As I said, there is also the problem of corruption and banditry.

I agree with Senator Bourne on the cross-border illegal trade and movement of arms. I have crossed the Mekong River myself in a small boat. I have been to Aranyaprathet. I climbed a large tree that gave me a view across the swamps of the border area. My brother, as a surgeon, was a volunteer Red Cross officer in Khao I Dang and other camps along the border. I visited Cambodia as a student 28 years ago and went to Phnom Penh and Siem Reap to see Angkor Wat. At that time it was a peaceful country and a happy place to visit. But from my experience in looking at the border, and from all that we know, that happiness has been totally squandered.

I have been given only a few minutes to speak in this debate. I support all that has been said about there being no lethal aid to the armed force of Cambodia but rather that our assistance is in training and demobilisation. There does need to be a disciplined armed force. It does need to be trained. There does need to be an instrument for stability and security for the people of that country. With all of the assistance from Australia and other countries, we must respect the sovereignty of Cambodia and do what we can to reinforce its own integrity and its own stability in the years ahead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last year I was fortunate enough to be one of the parliamentary delegates to the United Nations General Assembly in New York and was able to meet and talk with Lieutenant General Sanderson, an outstanding Australian who played an incredible role in resolving the political problems in Cambodia in the run-up to the successful election. At that time, it was evident that the holding of elections would not resolve Cambodia's problems.

PARA.TAB: Despite the hype, there were many absurd statements and a lot of self-congratulatory comments. That election simply provided an opportunity for Cambodia to move forward; it did not guarantee in any way its success. I note that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), in his statement, quoted himself from June 1993. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The important thing to appreciate is that the democratic foundations for the country's future have now been strongly laid, and it is essentially now for the Cambodian people and parties themselves to resolve how they want to be governed. It is neither possible nor desirable for the international community to try to micro-manage each step of the way.

That provides him with something of a problem. There is clearly a need for some `micro-management' in some areas if Cambodia is to overcome the disastrous internal problems created by the Khmer Rouge. The minister continued:

The Australian Government has never been either ignorant or naively optimistic about the massive scale of the problems that would have to be dealt with by the newly elected Government, not least the problem of containing the Khmer Rouge (KR) after it walked away from the peace process in 1992. But we have taken the view from the outset that the KR insurgency would be containable and ultimately defeatable—in the same way that the communist insurgencies had been contained and ultimately defeated in Malaysia, Thailand and the Philippines—provided there was a government in place with democratic legitimacy, a continued cessation of the kind of direct external support the KR had received in the past, and continued support both for economic reconstruction and national institution-building from the international community.

I want to deal with this problem because it seems that it is the massive gap in this whole matter. With something like a per capita income of $210 per annum, Cambodia's nine million people are among the poorest and most disadvantaged in the world. As this statement says:

It is evident that Cambodia will need substantial long term international assistance in this task. The economy needs major structural development and reform. It lacks adequate infrastructure, power and communications; industry and manufacturing, to the extent they exist, are badly run-down; the country lacks a skilled and trained labour force; public administration and government is terribly weak; health and education services need to be rebuilt; and the judicial and regulatory systems are virtually non-existent. The situation is further complicated because of inadequate administrative structures, corruption, political uncertainty and real concern about security.

They are the major problems. My concern is: what is being done about the major problems? Until we can establish that this country is capable of providing a better future for its population than the Khmer Rouge is offering at the point of a gun, then the Khmer Rouge will have continual opportunities.

PARA.TAB: What is unnerving is that the IMF in a recent review was concerned about the slow rate of disbursement of international donor pledges and noted that this was holding up much needed reform of key sectors, such as agriculture. It is true that Australia has been diligent in disbursing its pledges, but the fact is that, without much greater support, Cambodia will continue to be at risk from the Khmer Rouge, no matter how hopeful our expectations are that insurgencies such as Malaysia would be capable of being diminished. Lieutenant General Sanderson has said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there would be serious concerns about providing pure military assistance to the military unless structural reforms and institutional reforms were put in place first of all.
That seems to me to be the essence of this matter.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—It is a little difficult to please the opposition. One is asked to produce a detailed statement of explanation of the basis on which we are proceeding, an evaluation of the security situation and an explanation of what we are spending and why. One does that in great detail—54 paragraphs worth—and still there are complaints, whinges and grumbles of one kind or another. But that is fair enough because that is what we have had over the entire period we have been trying to wrestle with the Cambodian problem. I guess it would be too much to hope for some graciousness to be at last demonstrated at this stage.

PARA.TAB: The essence of the opposition's problems with the statement seem to come down to four themes, emphasised with differing degrees of stress by the various contributors to the debate. One theme is the suggestion that there has been no consistent or coherent approach to the whole Cambodian problem over the years that we have been wrestling with it. A second theme is that the analysis we have offered of the situation as it exists today and what we can do about it is simplistic, trite, banal, inadequate and inappropriate in those ways to deal with the nature of the problem we have. A third criticism, most notably articulated by Senator MacGibbon, was that we are spending too much. A fourth criticism, most evident from Senator Baume, is that we are apparently spending too little. That seems to cover the broad ground. There were some other specific matters raised by Senator Newman which I will try to pick up along the way, but I will address those basic themes.

As to the suggestion of an absence of a consistency or coherence in the government's approach since we started to try to help to resolve this problem, indeed from the mid-1980s onward, I do not think there is foundation for that. We have always acknowledged the scale and the size of the Khmer Rouge problem. Indeed, anyone witnessing the horrors of the killing fields could hardly fail to appreciate the devastating impact that experience has had on the Cambodian people and the need to try as an international community to do something about it.

We have taken the view from the outset that the Khmer Rouge problem could be contained and ultimately defeated, as I have said in the statement, in exactly the same way that similar communist insurgencies had been contained and ultimately defeated in Malaysia, Thailand and the Philippines, provided a number of conditions were satisfied: first, that there was a government in place with democratic legitimacy; secondly, that there was a cessation of the external support that had fuelled the continuation of conflict for so long and, in particular, fuelled the capacity of the Khmer Rouge to wage it; and, thirdly, that there had to be some major support for economic reconstruction, national institution building and similar things coming from the international community.

That was really what the peace process was all about—trying to put in place those three elements. Up until 1989 people struggled with a political solution that would involve a process of agreement between the four warring factions to form some kind of interim government which could create the conditions for, ultimately, democratic elections. That did not prove possible for a whole variety of reasons, including the suspicion, distrust and indeed hatred that they all felt for each other. It was for that reason that Australia did come up with the proposal, subsequently implemented, not to try to create a quadripartite government with sovereign executive authority; rather it would get the UN to play that role and create the conditions which would lead to a democratically elected government. That is indeed what happened, albeit not in quite the way we had all hoped: the Khmer Rouge opted out of the process very early on. Nonetheless, the process did produce a democratically elected government.

The second thing we had to achieve was the cessation of the proxy war; the support that the major external powers, including China in particular and other countries, were giving to the Khmer Rouge; the support that Vietnam and Russia, then the Soviet Union, standing behind it were giving to Hun Sen's government in Phnom Penh; and the support of other major players, including the United States and some of the ASEAN states, who were in the picture as well.

It was the case that the whole peace plan was constructed on the basis of what was necessary to create the conditions for that withdrawal of international military support for the warring parties to occur. The great single achievement—whatever else might have been less than a complete achievement—of the UN peace plan was to get those external patrons and players out of the game, and that situation has continued to the present day. Those on the other side who do not acknowledge the significance of that achievement are being a little ungracious. That really was what we were all about.

The third thing we had to achieve was the creation of conditions for major international support to flow. That was not going to happen while there was in place a government lacking any degree of democratic legitimacy. We needed the kind of process we had been through to produce that situation. We now have that international support flowing under the chairmanship of Japan through the ICORC process, the International Conference on the Reconstruction of Cambodia. It is to be hoped that, over time, that will produce the strengthening of the economic and governmental institutions of the country that are so obviously necessary.

Right from the outset—Senator Baume clearly acknowledged this—we have taken the position that the election process itself, in satisfying all of these three conditions that I just mentioned, would not necessarily result in the achievement of the kind of stable, peaceful and democratic society that we wanted. An enormous amount was always going to depend on the capacity of the Cambodian people to work in a united, effective and committed way to build their own country, something they could not do, certainly without international assistance but, equally, something that the international community could not impose or guarantee without their assistance.

That has been the consistent theme of our approach to all this right from the outset. As I say in the statement, all this was our view at the outset and it remains our view today. If in fairness we stand back and look at this process, with all the agonising twists and turns it has taken, we will see that those basic themes have been running through it and they persist today.

We come to the second problem: the alleged triteness, banality or simplicity of the response allegedly contained in the government's statement today, which is that this continuing problem of Khmer Rouge insurgency can somehow be quickly fixed by the kind of military support injection that we are here proposing. Let me say this: we make it very clear in the statement that, while the military support in getting a competent, disciplined and effective army together is a necessary condition for creating a better security environment than exists at the moment, it is not a sufficient condition. Of course it will have to be accompanied by a major effort on the part of the Cambodian government to get its act together in all the ways that it has not been doing so successfully in the last few months of this year. That point is made very explicitly in paragraph 36 of the statement. Everything we are doing demonstrates our seriousness of purpose in making that point.

The government is not just giving the additional military assistance that is involved in this statement; it is giving $92 million worth of civil aid over the course of four years, most of which is designed to be directly helpful to infrastructure development, the delivery of social programs and the sorts of things that are necessary, quite apart from delivering immediate benefits to the Cambodian people, to assist the credibility of the Cambodian government. We are recognising the necessity for much more financial support to be given for that purpose than purely on the military side.

TALK.START.PARA: —And, indeed, I said that was the most important support.

—I am not suggesting everyone from the opposition had exactly the same range of hang-ups about the statement; I am just suggesting that these are themes that came through. This sort of issue was most clearly the subject of Senator MacGibbon's criticism. He seemed to think that we had some rather naive and simplistic view about what throwing money at the military problem might achieve.

PARA.TAB: It is important to realise—and we acknowledge this in the statement—that the government is not suggesting that the Australian contribution will be in any way crucial to addressing the problem of training. It will be helpful, but it will not be crucial. It is going to need much more international support. That support is flowing from other countries. It is flowing from at least two, probably three, of the ASEAN countries. It is flowing from the United States and France. This is as well as the assistance that is being given by way of mine clearing operations.

It is a matter for the other countries themselves to announce precisely what they want to put on the public record about what they are doing and what they are proposing to do. The government knows what they are doing. We know what they are talking about doing by way of additional assistance, but through the ordinary course of international diplomacy and international relations it is not for me but for them to announce what they are doing in this respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —When will we know?

—Hopefully over the next few weeks or months. The government is doing its best to encourage the development of machinery, in particular through the ambassadors on the ground in Phnom Penh, to ensure that we are not doubling up and falling over each in this respect. That was part of the theme of my contribution to the debate on all this in Bangkok earlier this year. The government will continue to try to play a helpful role, if it is indeed helpful, in that respect.

PARA.TAB: In respect of the notion that—to the extent that this came through in some of the contributions—this kind of military assistance is not by itself going to be of any particular utility, either because of the scale of the problem with which we are dealing or because of the notion that we really ought to be spending the money on something else, let me say that, when it comes to spending money on something else, of course we need to spend a lot of money as an international community on supporting the non-military side of the effectiveness equation, but it is not a matter of `either . . . or'; it is a matter of `both . . . and'.

Effective development cannot proceed without a sense of security. The two things need to go hand in hand. It does seem to be the case that, without the injection of some support from the international community, we are not going to break the back of the initial capital expenditure on barracks and training facilities to get over the lack of training and discipline that exists at the moment. It will need a surge of support of some kind. That is why we are trying to do it.

A lot depends on one's assessment of the scale of the opposition with which one is dealing. Senator Newman was introducing a note of scepticism about the numbers that are in the government's paper. Senator MacGibbon seemed a bit more inclined to accept them at face value. All I can say is that the numbers we have given, both now and going back over the last two or three years, represent all the best evidence available to us. There is no attempt to gild the lily either way and no attempt to conceal anything. That is a frank assessment as we see it.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, just the effect of them.

—Of course, as Senator Newman keeps interjecting and Senator MacGibbon was saying at one stage, we have to treat seriously numbers of this order of magnitude because the nature of guerrilla operations are such that small numbers of people, if they are well armed, well trained and ideologically committed and directed, can do an awful lot of damage. All I am saying in that respect is: please understand that the nature of problem is not such that this is unmanageable.

PARA.TAB: The government believes it is containable. We believe it is ultimately defeatable, but a lot depends on progress being made simultaneously on all these fronts—getting the military's act together and getting the government's act together. So long as the government does not have its act together and so long as there is an undisciplined military perpetrating a number of the things that are causing distress in the countryside, it will not be creating an environment in which there will be that confidence on the part of the people or that morale on the part of military itself which will produce the results we all want. All of these things have to work together.

We happen to believe that the signs were there. In the first six to nine months of the existence of the new government, those conditions were being met, and gradually the pieces were falling into place. I had been accused of waxing and waning in my assessments of the situation. It is the case that, when I was in Cambodia in April this year, I came away feeling very up-beat and very optimistic indeed about the situation that I found. The landscape was littered with problems, many of them—in the human rights area, in particular—needing a huge amount of additional attention, but they did seem to be manageable. What happened, as we all now know, is that in May-June we had the debacle of the military adventure—misconceived, ill-executed—producing disastrous results in Pailin and Anlong Veng. As a result, morale tended to collapse and with it the effectiveness of the government. It has been a long, slow haul to try to recover ground, but I believe it is recoverable.

On the subject of spending too much, we had Senator MacGibbon querying the total of something like $30 million that will, indeed, be spent in calendar year 1995, with a combination of the proportion of the $92 million aid program and the military expenditure. I ask Senator MacGibbon to please compare that with the nearly $10 billion we are spending on the defence budget this year and the $1.4 billion we are spending on the aid budget. Without my going into any more comparative analysis, I ask Senator MacGibbon to please try to consider that it might just be arguable that this is money worth spending if, indeed, it is going to have a degree of effectiveness.

Senator MacGibbon queried what the money was going to be spent on. Three million dollars of it is on the existing defence cooperation program, which is not about training so much as it is about providing communications systems and so on. It is all spelt out in the news release. There is a maritime workshop. English language training is part of it, as is mine clearance. (Extension of time granted) The proportion of the $92 million will be spent not on training but on child health care, education, human rights, rehabilitation of infrastructure, agriculture and, again, demining.

In terms of answering Senator Newman's questions about why we are not spending more of this extra $3 million on demining, we genuinely believe that the mining problem has been pretty well addressed by the quite wide ranging components of international support that are in now place. Quite apart from our own budgetary and personnel contribution, there are a number of other countries involved in the mine clearance project. Paragraph 38 of the statement indicates that it is not only Australia which is involved but Belgium, Canada, France, New Zealand, the Netherlands, Norway and the United States. Indeed, the US has quite a number of personnel engaged in this project, with quite a significant capital commitment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Less than one per cent cleared.
—Sure, but the nature of the problem is such that—
—Huge.

—Yes, but we cannot do it by throwing even more resources at it than those that are there at the moment. The CMAC operation is very well run. The computer database has been established. The training programs are in place. A lot of the problem is that a number of the areas where the mines need to be cleared are insufficiently secure at the moment to enable the process to take place.

PARA.TAB: I simply do not accept that there is any rational justification for the argument that too much money is being spent. As to Senator Baume's argument that too little is being spent, that is just making the point that the international community needs to make a major, continued commitment, particularly on institution building, infrastructure support, social policy support, human rights, justice, and law enforcement support—all of which are very much part of the program at the moment. I repeat, finally: if we were just throwing money at it to try to resolve the military side of the problem without simultaneously making a major effort on all those other dimensions of it, then I think it would be challengeable. But I think we can hold our heads up in terms of the contribution that we are making there.

As to one or two other points that Senator Newman raised, she wanted to know where Australian personnel were going to be located and what the security regime applicable to them would be. I think it needs to be said that there will be only six members of the ADF deployed as part of this particular strategy over and above the 15 or so military personnel that are already there as part of the mine clearing exercise—

TALK.START.PARA: —Thirteen.

—Thirteen plus the defence attache and his assistants attached to the embassy. Indeed, I think only one ADF officer is expected to be there more or less for the duration of this. That is the person who will be associated with the construction of the facility.

PARA.TAB: But to finish what I was saying about expenditure of the money, $3 million of the $8 million that Senator MacGibbon referred to will go on the existing defence cooperation programs that I have already mentioned. Some $2 million of that is out of the aid program and will go directly to support the demobilisation activity. The remaining $3 million will be spent as a one-off package which will involve further work, which is spelt out in the statement, designing an overall training program, training junior officers in Australia—that is a large part of the financial commitment that is involved there—and providing design assistance and the construction funds for the RCAF to construct an additional training facility. I think Senator Newman's scepticism about whether the money can be accounted for with only a limited number of personnel being involved is accounted for by that response I have just given.

As to the security of the ADF personnel, limited though their numbers might be, we have given a detailed assessment in paragraph 44 of the statement about the overall security environment both now and as we assess it as being likely to be in the aftermath of this announcement. Beyond that, I can simply say this: obviously the security situation both of the ADF personnel and the wider Australian community in Cambodia is of prime importance. It has been very closely examined in the context of making this decision and obviously one of the most difficult single issues has been to weigh and balance the worth of what we are doing against the possible increase in the risk.

All that one can really say is that the security situation does vary from place to place, from time to time. The protection of ADF personnel is the responsibility, and will remain the responsibility, of the RCAF. Acknowledging the problems that are associated with relying on the RCAF in its present condition, we have to make the judgment that it may be necessary to further review the security situation from time to time. Security conditions and individual areas will be taken into account in the deployment of ADF personnel and they will not be deployed to areas where there is an assessed high risk of attack from the Khmer Rouge.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The minister is no doubt aware that today's balance of payments figure for October came in at $1.65 billion seasonally adjusted, or $1.85 billion on the trend estimate, and that the current account deficit for the first four months of this financial year is just under $9 billion, or 45 per cent worse than this time last year. If the balance of payments continues along this path for the remainder of this financial year Australia will have a record current account debt of $27 billion, 50 per cent higher than the budget forecast. In those circumstances what does the government intend to do with this balance of payments crisis?

—The note of deathly drama in Senator Hill's voice is a little bit misplaced, at least as far as the October figures—the monthly figures—announced today are concerned because they are significantly below market expectations. They are also significantly below the $1.8 billion of the last month, significantly below the $2.2 billion of the previous month and significantly below the $1.8 billion in July. So if the opposition is looking to derive some nourishment, excitement, gloom, funereal maudlin anxiety from this month's figures, it cannot do so because bearing in mind all the caveats and all the qualifications one always advances about particular month's figures, it is the case that there was a substantial decrease in the merchandise trade deficit.

PARA.TAB: Exports rose by five per cent with the most significant rises, again as is often the case, in the elaborately transformed area, and imports rose by comparison only two per cent. So if one is looking for an analysis of the present situation there is nothing but joy. I just draw attention to the absurdity of the opening bars of this little cadenza we had from Senator Hill today. Of course, the figures for the last quarter, the September quarter, are not so good—it blew out higher than we had hoped for. The environment has been one characterised in particular by a pretty substantial growth in imports and, in particular, capital imports. But, of course, as we have constantly said, that volume of capital goods imports increase is very closely associated with the recovery, and some deterioration in the current account deficit simply had to be expected at this stage of the cycle, given the strength of the economy.

There is no doubt about the underlying strength of the economy. Investment, about which the opposition used to be asking questions every second day of the week for the first half of this year, is now growing strongly. When is the last time the opposition asked a question about the investment figures? No, the opposition does not want to know about investment figures because the news there is good and the opposition is not in the business of acknowledging that.

Underlying plant and equipment investment rose 15.6 per cent over the year to June. This, of course, is an increase in the imports of capital equipment. It is also the case that manufactured exports continued to respond well to the improved economic environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the unemployed?

—Senator Vanstone, you are just showing your conspicuous ignorance if you make that point because the job situation is absolutely first class at the moment with something over 200,000 jobs being created in the last few months alone, as you well know—90,000 of them from the long-term unemployed as a result of the success to date already of the Working Nation statement. PARA.TAB: If there is to be any further deterioration in the current account deficit it will be moderated to some significant extent by the strength not only of the overall recovery, generating overall strength there, but also of Australia's exports and the increased competitiveness of the Australian economy. Once again, the opposition does not know how to do anything else but talk the country down, talk the economy down, and in this instance the opposition got it totally wrong in its references to this month's payments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. All we ask for is a touch of realism. TALK.START.PARA: —That's exactly what happened in the late `80s.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know this is something about which Senator West has a particular interest and that it has been the subject of some debate in recent times.
