We do regard that as an essential element of the policy formulation process in a democratic society. So the government values the constructive contribution that Australia's business and community leaders have brought to the open debate on these important national issues. I and my colleagues hope that they will continue to contribute in the way that they have.

PARA.TAB: In the Uruguay Round negotiations, for example, conducted by several of my predecessors and, ultimately, by Senator Cook, the Australian government's Trade Negotiations Advisory Group, chaired by Geoff Allen, was closely involved in the formulation of Australia's negotiating strategies and in conveying outcomes to the business community. This high level of close business government collaboration has been publicly recognised by Mr Allen, who said at the time:

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, concerns the Timor Gap treaty which was signed by him in 1989 and which is now under dispute at the International Court of Justice. Is it true that the treaty is the only legal agreement anywhere in the world that effectively recognises Indonesia's right to rule East Timor? Would the minister please remind us of the basis of the government's decision to negotiate the treaty? Was the fact that the people of East Timor have never had the opportunity to exercise their right to self-determination considered by the government? Is the government confident of Australia's winning the case on anything other than procedural grounds?

—It is not the case that the Timor Gap treaty is the only legal agreement anywhere in the world that effectively recognises Indonesia's right to rule in East Timor. There are some 24 countries which have signed treaties with Indonesia which contain clauses defining Indonesia as that territory which is deemed by the laws of Indonesia to be subject to Indonesian sovereignty. A treaty which contains such a provision, if concluded after 1976, can of course be regarded as evidence that, for all effective purposes, the relevant state party recognises East Timor. The following 24 states have signed such treaties: Austria, Brunei, Dar es Salaam, Bulgaria, Canada, China, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Hungary, India, Italy, Japan, the Republic of Korea, New Zealand, Norway, Pakistan, the Philippines, Saudi Arabia, Singapore, Sweden, Switzerland, Thailand, and the United Arab Emirates.

PARA.TAB: In addition—and this is in answer to those who say that Australia is the only country in the world that has recognised Indonesian de jure sovereignty over East Timor—it is the case that several countries have made public statements explicitly recognising Indonesian sovereignty. Those countries include India, Papua New Guinea and the United States of America—although the US has said that it recognises incorporation of East Timor into Indonesia, without recognising that a valid act of self-determination has taken place.

In addition, a number of states have also indicated that they have recognised the incorporation of East Timor at some stage since 1976 and are doing this by way of explanation of their vote at the UN General Assembly; Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, Bangladesh, Canada, Sweden, Papua New Guinea, India, Oman and Jordan are in that category. So when we add all of those up and take out the double counting, there are, I think, 31 countries in total that can be regarded as having expressly or impliedly recognised that degree of sovereignty. That is as to the first point.

As to the basis of the government's decision to negotiate the treaty, we made the judgment—or an earlier government than us made the judgment—back in 1979 that the situation in East Timor was, for all practical purposes, likely to be irreversible and, under those circumstances, it did make sense to try to negotiate some outcome to the contested border between Australia and that part of Indonesia because, until that border issue was resolved, among other things, there was an inability to address the question of exploration and production in what was potentially a very major oil province. Yes, there was a resource motivation for this; it has never been suggested otherwise. But if we are thinking in terms of assisting the East Timorese people, they had a much better chance of getting the benefits from that resource as a result of it being developed than of it, of course, lying idle through some protracted political squabble that was unlikely ever to be finally resolved in their favour. That was the judgment that was made in 1979. It was repeated by us in 1985, and was the basis for the signing of the treaty in 1991.

The honourable senator asks about self-determination. I am, of course, conscious of the argument that the East Timorese have not had sufficient opportunity to exercise the right of self-determination. I do not want to comment specifically on that question because it is one of the matters in issue in the court case. But I have said on many occasions on the public record, most recently on 14 November and in a speech on 25 November, that I believe that the right of self-determination can be exercised consistently with Indonesia's sovereignty. Indeed, there is a big case for self-determination being more effectively recognised through better protection and recognition of human rights.

As to our confidence in relation to the case, it would be inappropriate to canvass the arguments. But our view, in brief, remains that Portugal's attitude is not only regrettable but has no basis in international law and is, in fact, misconceived to the extent that Portugal has no real dispute with Australia. We are confident of success in the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The minister would be aware of the anticipation within the horticultural industries to the government's response to the Industry Commission report on horticulture and the subsequent task force report. I understand that this matter was considered by federal cabinet yesterday, and I would ask the minister if he could inform the Senate of the outcome.

—I am pleased to advise the Senate that federal cabinet has endorsed a multimillion dollar program to revitalise the citrus industry. Senator Boswell was interjecting about this a moment ago; he might like to listen—he should stop counting the numbers.

PARA.TAB: The program is part of a broad-ranging package of measures in response to the recommendations of the Industry Commission and the horticultural task force report. A market diversification program which will be funded by the federal government at a cost of $9 million over five years will assist industry efforts to reduce its reliance on the juice concentrates sector and to increase sales of fresh fruit and fresh fruit juice, with a focus on exports.

The program will be developed in direct consultation with citrus growers, processors, fruit juice manufacturers and the Australian Horticultural Corporation. Cabinet rejected the Industry Commission's recommendations that all fruit and vegetable beverages should be taxed at 21 per cent. Cabinet decided that all fruit and vegetable juice products containing at least 25 per cent juice should be taxed at the wholesale sales tax concessional rate of 11 per cent.

The termination of the local content rule will place adjustment pressure on industries currently benefiting from this measure, particularly citrus growers. Cabinet considered that the removal of the partial sales tax exemption, as proposed by the Industry Commission, would place too much additional burden on these industries.

The government, importantly, has also agreed to the extension of the taxation write-off on expenditure on all new horticultural plantations. This has important implications for all horticultural industries. The details of these taxation write-offs will be considered by the government over the next few months.

Cabinet also decided to remove the AHC's export trading powers in response to concerns raised with us from horticultural exporters, and to reject the Industry Commission's recommendation for industry levies to be decoupled from the AHC, because it would impede progress towards improving the national and international focus of Australian horticultural industries.

These decisions follow provisions in the 1994-95 budget, which included funding for the Australian Horticultural Corporation—the AHC—of $4.5 million over the next four years for it to undertake its role as the change agency for the horticultural industry; funding of $0.5 million for the Horticultural Policy Council for a further two years, which will allow it to continue working towards the development of a peak national body for horticulture; and funding of $0.59 million as the Commonwealth's contribution to the tri-state fruit fly strategy. This program will increase the industry's export opportunities.

Australian horticultural industries are on the threshold of a significant growth phase, driven largely by a major surge in exports over the last two to three years. I have appointed my Senate colleague and Parliamentary Secretary, Senator Nick Sherry, to chair two groups to oversee the implementation of these decisions. I would like to take the opportunity—along with, I am sure, the horticultural industry—to commend Senator Sherry for the job that he has done so far on this restructuring package. The government has responded to all of the recommendations directed towards it. The opportunity is now available to the horticultural industry to take up the challenge.

Such work is important as high levels of erosion could increase the Hinchinbrook Channel's turbidity to such an extent that seagrasses might be damaged.

PARA.TAB: The development site is to be controlled and managed in accordance with a turbidity control plan. Unfortunately, I understand that the clearing of the mangroves took place in absence of such a plan and it is fortunate indeed that the wet season has not begun.

I met with the developer, Mr Williams, this morning in Sydney. I recognise that there is an urgent need for stabilisation of the site, as Senator Chamarette referred to in her question, irrespective of the outcome of the discussions that I have spoken about. —On 17 November Senator Herron asked me a question on pathology services. I now have an answer for the honourable senator. Over recent years, the government has embarked upon a program of initiatives to restructure the pathology industry and to strengthen arrangements relating to the funding of pathology services under Medicare. In particular, in the 1991-92 budget, a series of major reforms was announced to achieve a more cost effective and efficient Australian pathology industry. These restructuring arrangements were undertaken in cooperation with the pathology industry and profession. Prior to the restructuring, pathology expenditure under Medicare had been growing at an annual rate of 13.7 per cent.

PARA.TAB: The bills to which Senator Herron refers and the measures they contain are only part of the continuing series of initiatives the government is taking to ensure Australians have access to appropriate and quality pathology services which are affordable to both individuals and the nation. More recent measures include strengthening the powers of the Health Insurance Commission for addressing inappropriate servicing practices under Medicare. The government is aware of the recent growth in pathology outlays to which Senator Herron has referred. In 1993-94, pathology outlays grew by 10.9 per cent after two years of very low growth rates following the restructuring package.

Data for the first four months of 1994-95 indicates that the growth is continuing at a rate of 10.6 per cent. By contrast, in 1991-92 pathology outlays fell by 0.3 per cent and in 1992-93 the growth rate was 0.7 per cent. In the absence of restructuring, the long-term trend of 10 per cent growth would have applied throughout and expenditure would now be considerably higher. The situation for pathology is similar to that for the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and the introduction of co-payments for pensioners. That measure led to a reduction in outlays of some 15 per cent. After the initial impact, annual growth of five to six per cent applied. However, the fact that PBS prescription volumes are growing again does not negate the impact of the co-payment. The government recognises the need for further reform of pathology. It is working with the pathology industry and profession to identify the causes of the growth and to examine strategies to contain the growth in pathology utilisation and outlays.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 November Senator Kernot asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, a question concerning pay TV and the televising of a proposed super league rugby league competition. PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
There were a number of press reports speculating on News Limited's plans for a new `Super League' Rugby League competition.

However, at the moment there is no Super League competition, only rumours of its development, fuelled by press speculation. It is clear that the Australian Rugby League (ARL) is working with a number of parties about ensuring the future development of the code, but today there is no Super League.
The advice from the ARL is that it is planning to have an expanded competition with up to 20 rugby league clubs in the 1995 season.

Section 115 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 empowers the Minister for Communications and the Arts to specify an event which, in the Minister's opinion, should be available free to the general public. Paragraph 10(1)(e) of Schedule 2 to the Act imposes the condition on subscription television broadcasting licensees that the licensee will not acquire the right to broadcast an event specified under s.115 unless a national broadcaster or a commercial television broadcasting licensee has acquired the right to broadcast that event.

As both the Minister for Communications and the Arts and I stated in Parliament on 17 November, new competitions such as any proposed Super League are not exempt from these legislative provisions, nor does the Act distinguish between present and future events.
The Minister for Communications and the Arts, the Hon Michael Lee MP, stated in the House of Representatives on 17 November 1994:

ANSWER.PARA: "If I consider that some event is of national sporting significance and should be included in the anti-siphoning list, I can do that at any time; it gets gazetted and then it is subject to disallowance."

PARA.TAB: The Minister then referred to the fact that it is not possible to list an event which cannot be adequately described for the purposes of the anti-siphoning list.

The Minister is not prepared to fuel speculation about what Mr Murdoch's plans might be but he notes that the only public comment about News Limited's plans came from Mr Ken Cowley, chief executive of News Limited. The Daily Telegraph Mirror of 12 November reported that:

ANSWER.PARA: "Mr Cowley said News Limited's super league plans on Pay TV would not include insisting on exclusive rights."

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Communications and the Arts will continue to monitor developments such as the Super League closely and will list further events if and when he considers it appropriate. In doing so he will be utilising the power given to him under s.115 of the Broadcasting Services Act. The Minister will in any event direct the ABA to monitor, investigate as necessary and report to him on the general operation of the s.115 list.
I stress the Government's continued commitment to ensuring that major sporting events that are currently televised free will remain on free-to-air television.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 November, Senator Watson asked me a question on air traffic control training. I have received an answer from the Minister for Transport. Again, it is quite a long and detailed answer. I seek leave of the Senate to have it incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: The Civil Aviation Authority has advised that:
1.The relocation of new entrant Air Traffic Control (ATC) training is proceeding to schedule and courses are set to commence at the end of March 1995 in Melbourne and Brisbane.

2.The new curriculum is based on a "hands-on" approach to train controllers for the specific skills they need. The training environment is located close to the new Air Traffic Services centres at Brisbane and Melbourne, rather than as a program undertaken by the University of Tasmania. One of the benefits of the new arrangements is that appropriately skilled Air Traffic Controllers will be available after 12-15 months training instead of up to three years under the previous program with the University.
These arrangements follow a comprehensive review, undertaken by the CAA, of its training program for Air Traffic Controllers.

The Auditor-General undertook a project performance audit of the Centre for Air Traffic Services in 1993. In his report (Audit Report No. 8 1993-94), the Auditor-General noted that the Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) review of the process followed by the CAA in reaching a decision on the means of delivery of future ATC training indicates that a broad approach has been taken to enable consideration of the wide range of factors impacting such a decision. The report noted that the ANAO has sighted sufficient evidence to confirm that action taken by the CAA has been directed at satisfying its primary ATC training objective of implementing a training program that would produce competent Air Traffic Controllers to international standards and maintain that competency in the most cost-effective manner.

3.The Authority has taken a decision to provide Australian industry with the opportunity to develop simulation systems which will meet its longer term needs rather than proceeding with immediate acquisition of equipment which is available from overseas sources. To facilitate this, interim arrangements are being considered to support the training system during the first year of its operation.

4.New intakes totalling 50 in 1995 and 80 in subsequent years are planned. In addition training of current Authority staff for conversion to Air Traffic Control from Flight Service and Airways Data Systems Officer duties will continue and about 40 such officers will commence training in 1995.

SPEECH.PARA: In his response to Senator Hill today, Senator Gareth Evans, in his normal bumbling, un-understanding of economics way, was completely misleading. The facts are that today we have seen a disastrous balance of payments figure for October. That comes on top of a string of disastrous balance of payments figures which are plunging this nation into potentially the largest balance of payments deficit that we have ever faced.

PARA.TAB: The government's own budget estimate for the balance of payments deficit this financial year, 1994-95, is $18 billion, which is about four per cent of GDP. Last year, the figure, the actual out-turn, was $16 billion, which was 3.75 per cent of GDP. So even on the government's own figures, it expects a blow-out in the balance of payments figure for 1994-95.

Yesterday, the revised September quarter balance of payments figures revealed a record September quarter deficit of $6.1 billion. That was higher in dollar terms than the previous record, which was in September 1989. It was that level of deficit that prompted the then Treasurer and now Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to engineer what he called the recession we had to have, with all the disastrous consequences that that has had for Australia.

Today, the October monthly figures came out. They reveal a seasonally adjusted deficit figure of $1.65 billion, or $1.85 billion on the trend estimates. So for the first four months of this financial year, the current account deficit is almost $9 billion. That is almost half as large again as the figure for the comparable period last year, which was itself dangerously and unsustainably high. If the level of the first four months of this financial year remains steady for the entire year, the year as a whole result will be a deficit of $27 billion, which is $9 billion, or 50 per cent, higher than the government's budget estimate, which was unacceptably high anyway.

A comparison of the first four months of this financial year with the first four months of the last financial year shows some equally disconcerting figures. The merchandise trade deficit has deteriorated by $2.6 billion, which is a 366 per cent deterioration over last year. The net income deficit, which is mainly interest on foreign debt, has deteriorated by $274 million, despite falling interest rates. Of course, that deficit will rise significantly in coming months as higher interest rates begin to take effect on repayments.

For the first four months of this year, exports were only about the same as they were for the first four months of last year. On the other hand, imports were up by a sizeable 11 per cent, an increase of $2.6 billion over that period. The appalling state of Australia's external account will be the Achilles heel that once again forces the Australian government to rapidly and savagely tighten monetary policy in a desperate attempt to slow economic activity and relieve pressure on the balance of payments.

What we are seeing is the emergence of precisely the same problem that we had in the late 1980s which saw Australia crash into the most prolonged recession since the 1930s. TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the Senate unduly, given our need to get on to other matters. Today I wanted to raise, and comment on, a comment made by Senator Bolkus, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, at the government's launching of its citizenship campaign on 9 November this year. In reality, that launch was simply a glittering public relations exercise for the government at the taxpayers' expense.

PARA.TAB: In his speech at the launch, Senator Bolkus described Australia as `an independent nation in all but law'. What an extraordinary statement, even for this minister. Has Senator Bolkus not heard of the Australian constitution—the document from which this government and this nation derive their legal standing? Or is he saying—indeed, I am sure he did not mean to—that his government has no legal standing?

The Australian constitution gains its standing from two factors. First, it is a document which comes from the people of Australia. It was voted on and accepted by state referenda in the late 1890s, and in 1900 in the case of Western Australia. It is also an act of the British parliament—the Commonwealth Constitution of Australia Act 1900—which granted legal independence to the six colonies in Australia to become a new independent federation.

In the constitution, specific power is given to the Australian people to make all future changes to the constitution—the legal framework of our nationhood—via section 128 of the referendum provision which gives Australian people control of their constitution. There was further Australian and complementary British acts which sought to and did further entrench and clarify beyond any doubt whatsoever the concept of legal independence in Australia. These were the Statute of Westminster in 1931 and, even more significant and much more recent, the Australia Act of 1986.

I do not know whether Senator Bolkus was merely ignorant of these important, basic constitutional facts or whether he just did not understand them. For Senator Bolkus to tell a group of new Australian citizens in particular—but the Australian community as a whole—that this country is not independent at law is not only wrong, it is also mischievous. He may have been sounding a warning, although I doubt it, against his own Labor government's moves to undermine our national independence—that great independence that we have treasured for so many years—because it is undermining that independence in several ways.

In particular, this government has gravely damaged Australia's real sovereignty through the abject failure of its economic policies which have led to a seven-fold increase in Australia's debt to the rest of the world since Labor came to power in 1983 to a figure that now exceeds $200 billion in gross terms. That figure compares with a figure of the order of $30 billion—a very manageable figure—when the Fraser government went out of office in March 1983. So that is a quite fundamental undermining of our real sovereignty and independence.

But Senator Bolkus may also have been referring—again, I doubt it very much—to the fact that this government of his is progressively undermining Australia's independence and sovereignty through its quite obsessive reliance on external treaties as a basis for its domestic policies. Labor seems to have become obsessed with handing over moral, if not legal, authority for our domestic affairs to unrepresentative, unelected international committees which hand down decisions and judgments on our domestic laws. If that is the thrust of Senator Bolkus's remarks, I suggest he hotfoot it posthaste to his Prime Minister and to the rest of the Keating government and take up this matter to stop this insidious transfer of our legal independence to overseas interests.

I conclude with the remark I made at the start. I find it absolutely extraordinary and inexplicable that a minister of the crown could, on such a significant occasion as the launch of a citizenship campaign—significant because of the effort that the government put into it and significant because of the importance of citizenship—describe Australia, `as an independent nation in all but law'.
